scenes.location: DAN PIENAAR SECONDARY SCHOOL FOR BOYS
characters: "YOU ARE NOW ENTERING SOWETO TOWNSHIP. NO PERSON WITHO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Pienaar school is a typical Johannesburg Afrikaan school. The students are mainly from middle-class families. School athletics are in progress. The stu- dents, in their smart school uniforms, are cheering enthusiastically a relay race on the immaculately-kept sports ground. GORDON NGUBENE, a 47-years-old African laborer is work- ing in the school garden. A few feet away is his 15- years-old son JONATHAN leaning against a wall watching the games. BEN DU TOIT, a 50-year-old Afrikaaner history teacher, is enthusiastically cheering his son JOHAN, a 15-years-old, who is leading neck-and-neck with another boy in the last leg of the race. The excitement increases as they approach the tape. Ben is beside himself, egging his son with shouts. The young teacher, VIVIERS, standing next to Ben, is shouting "come on Johan," and slapping the father on the back. Johan breasts the tape just ahead of the other boy. The ground is invaded by boys running to congratulate Johan. Ben hurries towards his happy but exhausted son; the prou father pushing his way through the animated boys. As he reaches Johan he pats him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was your best race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beat him, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did son. Come on, shower. They walk happily towards the school buildings in conver- sation, Johan being slapped on the back by friends. Ben stops to talk to Gordon who jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be expecting you. There isn't much to do, only weeding the marigolds and watering the lawn and flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be there, Mr. Ben'sir, Jonathan come to help me. Ben hadn't seen Jonathan.    He turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how's the algebra?   Still giving you trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with respect)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little, Mr. Ben'sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's working hard, Mr. Ben'sir, and your money will not be wasted. Emily and me will always thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he leaves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you both later. Gordon returns to his work a little distance further. A group of students are laughing and pushing each other boisterously. As they near Jonathan, two nudge each other and giggle. Then, one of them trips Jonathan. He falls to the ground and jumps up aggressively, about to attack the boy. Gordon shouts "Jonathan." The headmaster, MRS. CLOETE, aged 65 years, has observed the incident, but takes no action. Jonathan stands panting with rage.       He suddenly stri away towards the gate in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U ya phi? (Where are you going?) Jonathan turns to look at his father and continues to walk off. TITLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beer hall is a large complex with a drinking area with long rows of low benches.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Men sit drinking African beer in one-half and one gallon plastics containers. The place buzzes with noise. Several people are touting wares for sale. Suddenly a group of about twenty youths walks into the drinking area, obviously to cause trouble. The LEADER starts to address the clients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your children are starving and you are drinking. We demand freedom and our fathers are drunk. We ask you to boycott these beer halls. Revolution and drink don't work together! A large MAN WITH SIDEBURNS, obviously drunk, stands up, a stick in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do children talk like this to their fathers? They need thrashing. The man and several others advance on the boys. The boys run into the serving area, close the doors and start breaking up the place. Two police Land Rovers SCREECH to a halt outside. The boys run out through a side en- trance. They are chased by the police who are black. Jonathan and his best friend Wellington, also 15 years, are walking towards the beer hall when the boys come running out chased by the police. It is prudent for them to run down the street. The boys and police are bearing down on them. Their escape is cut off by the apperance of another police Land Rover. Two policemen, two blacks and two whites join in the capture. Jonathan, Wellington and about ten of the boys are arrested. As they are hundled into the vehicle, they protest their innocence without success and are driven away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The charge office is sparcely furnished with a long bench along a wall. There is a reception counter with Sgt: Van Zyl in charge. The boys are lined up against a wall. The sergeant stands with a tall blond man with a scar on his chin, CAPTAIN STOLZ.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The sergeant reads out a name and    looks at Stolz; if h nods the boy stands aside. After     this ritual, the one that Stolz has chosen are marched    to a waiting police and driven away. The others are     taken to the cells at the police station, these include    Jonathan and Wellington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC STOPS. The doors open. The 40 years-old- minister Bester comes to the door, then stands and greets his parishioners as they file out of the church. Amongst them, Ben Du Toit -- his wife, SUSAN, a clean- cut, immaculate, "toe-the-line" beauty and his son, Johan -- the blond, blue-eyed, tanned and torsoed fourteen- year-old every father dreams of. Susan greets friends and acquaintances, pausing to chat... mostly formalities. Johan, his eyes on a girl his age. She is with her father, Mr. Cloete, the headmaster -- she smiles at Johan from a distance; he waves awkwardly as she drives off with her parents. SUZETTE his daughter, sophisticated -- groomed. She takes her baby from the black nanny waiting in the car, carries the child to the group chatting with CHRIS, her husband. She shows it off proudly. Ben is chatting, concerned, to a WOMAN. She looks drawn and worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't come to church. He lies in bed all day, listening to his headphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered why he wasn't at school. Would it help if I came to see him? He's always seemed a good kid to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I'll phone and we can fix a time. Mrs. Coetzee smiles her gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben!   Ben! She's waving impatiently at him.     He crosses back to h Suzette's BABY is HOWLING.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She rocks it back and forth, holding it at arm's length. The BABY SCREAMS. The nanny comes forward -- Suzette hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Coetzee.    She looked worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's having trouble with her boy. He won't come to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you said you'd have a word with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! She smiles and walks him to the car affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Du Toit family. Susan is bringing out the salads. Chris, her son-in-law, is at the barbecue, stinging his eyes. Ben is bouncing his grandson, little Hennie, in a small, portable pool. The black nanny sits in attendance in the shade, a towel at the ready. The good life... ... Suddenly disturbed by... Gordon and Jonathan standing uncertain at the far side of the garden; Gordon's hat pressed flat against his chest, Jonathan defiant. Susan looks up -- as do each in turn -- curious at the intrusion... then the black nanny -- and finally Ben. After a moment, Ben walks up to Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon!   What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six cuts, like six knife gashes, revealed on the blood- stained buttocks of Gordon's son, who stands in painful, truculent embarrassment. Ben is shocked by the severity of the canning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not why I'm complaining, Mister Ben, sir. If he did wrong, I'd beat him myself. But he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did nothing and they wouldn't listen. They wouldn't believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Gordon.    But there must be a reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he wasn't doing anything wrong, Mister Ben, sir. And I believe him, I know my son! It's an injustice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the court?    Didn't he state his case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he know about court? Before he knew, it was all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think there is anything we can do about it now. Outside, peering     through the half-opened door, is Joh shocked at what     he sees. Ben tapes Jonathan on the he he pulls up his     shorts painfully, yet fiercely, anxio to cover himself     up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can get a lawyer to appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lawyer? That won't heal Jonathan's buttocks. Susan appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be out in a minute. She nods, ushering Johan away from the door back outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand, Mister Ben, sir. I don't want him to have a police record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be there for  the rest of his life and make it  difficult for him to get a job in  the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Gordon. I'm sure there'll be no record, it's such a minor case. Please don't worry. Ben calls Johan from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johan, get some iodine from the cupboard. Johan rushes in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about the wounds. They'll heal in time, Mister Ben, sir. It's the wounds here. (slaps his chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I worry about. Injustice... it festers. Johan comes back with a small bottle of medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gordon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rub it on the wounds and it will help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben watches   the black man and his son trudge down the long drive,   the father's arm on the son's shouldre. At the foot of   the drive the nose of an exotic Soweto cab can be seen   waiting... a large butterfly painted on the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben takes his place at the table.     Susan brings a piec of boerwors and a mug of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan has been caned, by the police. She places the boerwors and the beer before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School grounds of the Orlando Secondary School. Students are milling around in high spirits. One group is putting finishing touches to a banner reading: "no to aparhteid education." There are two other banners being carried around the school yard, followed by the younger children. They read: "No to the Oppressor's language" "Bantu education is slave education." A BOY, one of the eldest, aged about 18 years calls for silence. The STUDENTS immediately obey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all know why we are going to march. The crowd shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'No to Bantu education' 'No to apartheid' 'Freedom Now'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be discipline. We start marching from here and we'll join up with the others at the main road. Please take care of the younger ones. Let's go. The Students start marching led by one of the banners, singing a freedom song. Amongst them is Jonathan and Wellington. They are sing- ing. The march turns round one of the streets.

dialogues.speaker: CROSSROAD
dialogues.text: Several groups of students marchers converge to join the march that has already started, including Jonathan's group. There are several banners condeming Bantu education, apartheid, etc.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Examples:    "EQUAL EDUCATION NOW"

dialogues.speaker: "NO TO THE AFRIKAANS LANGUAGE"
dialogues.text: There are chants of slogans as they march:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If we learn Afrikaans vorster must learn Zulu.' 'Bantu education! Stinks! Stinks! Stinks!' 'Equal education! Now! Now! Now!' They also start singing a freedom song.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER UP STREET
dialogues.text: Three police Jeeps block the route of the march. A little distance behind are police troops carriers ('hippos'). About six police-dog-handlers in camouflage uniforms stand across the road waiting for the march to approach. As the march gets closer the students' singing increases in volume. The Soweto   police COMMANDANT steps forward with a loud- speaker in   hand.  He confronts the lead of the march. H signals for   them to stop. The dogs are straining at the leashes and   their handlers taunt the leading group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen to me, this is an illegal demonstration. I order you to disperse immediately. The Students start singing the African national anthem 'Nkosi Sikelele.' Children of 8, 9, 10 years singing lustily with their fists clenched as everyone else. Jonathan and Wellington singing. Camouflauged police scrambling out of Jeeps with guns and tear gas grenades. They stand with the rifles pointing at the marchers. The singing continues. The Commandant confers with a junior officer who hurries to the group of policemen and gives them instructions. The ones carrying tear gas move towards front. The police start donning gas masks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last warning. Disperse immediately or I will take action. A voice in the crowd shouts "Banutu education..." The crowd shouts back "Stinks, Stinks, Stinks." The Commandant gives a hand signal. Tear gas canisters are thrown into the crowd, the dog- handlers attack. There is panic with Students running in all directions, several choking. Some of the students start throwing stones at the police, hitting one in the face; he is helped away by a black policeman. Without warning, SHOOTING STARTS. Children drop, wounded; friends trying to help the dying and seriously wounded, others helped away. Some boys appear with dustbin lids as protection and they pelt the police with stones. The police in the 'hippos' are jumping off and pursuing Students, some SHOOTING. Woman grabs two of the running children age about 9/10 and hustles them into house. Jonathan and Wellington are running with      a group.  I distance the sound of an AMBULANCE SIREN.       A Jeep cu off their escape, they turn back running      as SHOTS ar FIRED towards them, a little girl drops,      shot in the back. Jonathan shouts to Wellington who       is ahead of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wellington!   Wellington! Wellington looks back, sees Jonathan trying to help the little girl. He runs back to help. Another girl, aged about 17 years, is also trying to help. Two policemen suddenly appear from behind a house, they are about 18 years old. The girl straightens up and confronts the two policemen shouting hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot me!   Come on, shoot me! Shoot me!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She slumps to the ground crying. Jonathan, Wellington and the Girl are hustled into a crowded van amid punches and kicks from the police. The van drives off leaving the injured Girl on the road, neighbors run to assist the Girl. As the van is passing, see a burning car, in the distance a building on fire; another AMBULANCE SIREN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B) The screams, the laughter of white kids playing at their school, massed in conviviality, Johan one. C) Behind, aboard a mower, motors Gordon, in the blue overall of a groundsman, intent in his task. OVER this white pacifist content, hear... ... GUNSHOTS, SCREAMS, TERROR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carnage, the dead, the wounded. The stunned bewilderment of blacks and police alike... even the latter unnerved by their own brutality. END MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soweto train rushing through suburb of Johannesburg. REVERSE SHOT FROM train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third-class carriage is crowded with African commuters returning to Soweto. The passengers represent all the social and economic strata of Soweto: laborers, factory workers, domestic servants, clerk secretaries, the unemployed, etc. In the carriage, Gordon, returning from work, standing. A LARGE middle-aged WOMAN is standing in the crowded aisle at one end of the carriage. She suddenly shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to man in front of her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful with your bag. Can't you see where it's touching?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing half-way down carriage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see where it's touching?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men of today only like looking. Laughter in the carriage.    Gordon is also enjoying the joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing by a door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the electricity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has electricity to do with it? A few voices also ask same question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today with the electricity they say: (in an affected voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Darling let's not switch off the light.' Laughter and voice saying "that's true."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing very near Gordon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you have electricity with those thick glasses of yours. With your eyes you couldn't find anything. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us, does your wife also wear thick glasses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know, she's your sister.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is more laughter. Suddenly a MAN jumps on his seat waving his arms -- he's about 40 years old -- in BLUE OVERALLS. He cannot take it any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet!   Thulani! Thulani! The noise goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are killing our children and you are making jokes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say hundreds of children have died and Soweto is burning.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON AND WOMAN
dialogues.text: talking about the information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white people, they will pay, and soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'They will pay, they will pay.' Since when have they been killing us, putting us in jails, starving our children to death, taking our land? Hundreds of years. And what have you men done? Only talk, talk, talk. You are not men. Sis. (Shit.) The conversations in the carriage become muted and seriou The train enters Soweto, there is smoke hanging over sev- eral parts of the township, and official buildings are on fire. Suddenly, the passengers are gripped by the seriousness o the situation. There are snatches of conversation such as: "That's the superintendent's office on fire." "I hope the children are home." "We have to dodge bullets tonight." "Vorster must hang for this." "I hope the world hears about this."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. A small three-room Soweto brick house -- The living room is modestly furnished. EMILY, Gordon's 40-year-old wife, is sitting on a narrow iron bedstead against the wall, clutching her youngest 2-year-old son -- Her mind is preoccupied. Sitting next to her is a ten-year-old daughter. Gordon is sitting on a chair at the table with his second eldest son, Robert -- aged 14 years -- standing by the side of the table -- sitting on an old easy chair is a Soweto resident with his 15-year-old DAUGHTER standing beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure it was Jonathan they took away? The girl glances at her father.    He coaxes her to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, baba, with Wellington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black parents, waiting. At the counter with Gordon, a large black man, STANLEY, a friend -- his big easy smile is working hard on a white policeman, the station SERGEAN VAN ZYL, about to run out of patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I understand, Baas, but is that all the names? There's no other list somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you. He's not in custody. Have you tried the hospital? Have you tried the mortuary? Gordon sucks in his breath audibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only suggesting the possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, what about John Voster Square?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I've tried to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Stanley walks up to a WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here too, sis Paulina, who are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They picked up my girl -- 13-year- old girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comforting her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are all searching. The policeman calls her -- she hurries to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white-uniformed assistant leads a line of African parents, reeking of sadness, into a cool room where metal drawers open from the walls. Stanley and JULIUS their black lawyer -- the two men seem to be very well-known, people shake hands with them, salute them -- Gordon and Emily's sadness is tinged with anger -- they have dignity, defiance, bowed with grief as they are. Stanley's large hand is placed gently on Emily's shoulder as they examine the dead faces before them. They belong to children, some    in torn, dirty clothes, others naked, some mutilated,    others whole and seeming unharmed, as if asleep, until    the small, neat hole in temple or chest and the small    crust of blood is brough to our attention. A woman behind them starts to scream. They look around to see her holding onto a drawer, her legs buckling. Another woman pulls her close to grieve with her. The assistant approaches them and after a soft exchange he writes a name on a tag and ties it onto the body. The woman can't, won't leave her dead child. Her friend has to pull her away.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The crowd parts to let them through.    Other women reach out to touch her. Gordon looks into the last drawer, Jonathan is not there. They make their way out past the other parents and a grou of mourning women sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon, Emily and their friends cross to Stanley's great white elderly Dodge, this "etembalami" with the big butte fly. For, amongst other things, he is the owner and driver of a pirate taxi. They get in. Stanley pauses -- looks across at a small red VW Beetle parked nearby, waiting. He shakes his head -- the VW flashes its lights and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside they sit in silence... recovering from the ordeal. Only Emily silently whispers "Thank God, thank God." After a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is our son... we must find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make more inquiries -- John Vorster Square -- the special branch -- but I don't hold out much hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lawyer, Julius!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black lawyer! Those Boers... the bastards'll kick him around till they lose him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Baas? If he asks, they will give him an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the boy was flogged he didn't help. Why should he help him now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon is at work already -- 8 AM -- mowing the lawn. He's intense, unsmiling, burdened as he goes about his task, expertly. Sounds of BEN and JOHAN LAUGHING coming from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Johan, in robes, their hair still wet from their showers, having an imaginary boxing match. Johan has Ben on the ropes, backs him out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben adjusts the sash of his robe and takes the offensive towards Johan, as he sees Gordon. JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Gordon. No response.   Ben does a double-take and stops playing. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Johan) Hold it, champ. He crosses the yard to Gordon, fluffing his hair dry, Johan follows behind. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon, you okay? No response again. Gordon continues to work.     Ben and Johan exchange puzzled looks. JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this Jonathan's day to help you? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he, recovering? Gordon stops, switches OFF the MACHINE, stands not lookin at Ben. GORDON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Mister Ben, sir -- the police took him. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again? JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrested many. They even deny they've got him. He's disappeared...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappeared? He's a child -- why didn't you tell me? Gordon just looks at him, sadly, patiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay!   I'll see what I can find out. Ben walks off with Johan as Gordon STARTS the MOWER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our gardener, yes. Probably nothing, but he's worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sumptuous lawyer's offices, Johannesburg. They're lush- carpeted. A black woman cleaner is finishing off her early-morning chores, packing up as white staff are be- ginning to arrive. They're fresh, shining, attractive -- whipping the covers off typewriters. A young black girl, smart, well-groomed, is carrying a tray of coffee, desk to desk. FOLLOW her as she approaches her employer's open office door. We hear his voice -- see him on the phone in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And when was this? He nods, makes notes. He's in shirtsleeves.        At his early, ready for action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngubene -- Jonathan Ngubene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffee girl enters, places a cup on Lewinson's desk, and retreats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get on to them straight away... Not at all -- I think better this time of morning -- after lunch, man, I'm a zombie. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- let you know straight away -- love to, Susan... Cheers! (puts down phone; presses his intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freda! Open an account... Du Toit. Benjamin Du Toit... Subject... Jonathan Ngubene.

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: -- CHATTERING out -- on Lewinson's headed note paper: To the Commissioner of Police Police Headquarters John Vorster Square Dear Sir, On behalf of our client, Gordon Ngubene, we are anxious to discover the whereabouts of his son...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Wellington, Jonathan's friend, is sitting alone in fear. Through the wall he can hear MOANING -- SCREAMS. He closes his eyes tight as if to shut out what he is hearing.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: -- CHATTERING out -- on police headquarters note paper: To Lewinson & Partners Solicitors Dear Sirs, With reference to your enquiry concerning Jonathan Ngubene, we suggest you take the matter up directly with the particular officer in charge...

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: Young black nurse carrying bedding -- corridor -- startled by moaning, screaming figure of black boy, being hustled on trolley into private ward. Boy is deposited on bed as policeman is posted outside.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: -- Lewinson's headed paper: ... the whereabouts of Jonathan Ngubene, aged 15, who was apparently detained by you...

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: -- Second heading: The type keys hesitate, tremble, for a considerable number of seconds, on and on, as if deliberately de- laying or uncertain how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: confronted by Gordon and Emily. She shakes her head vigorously, denying all knowledge, shows them the door.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: Dear Sirs, With reference to your enquiry seeking the whereabouts of Jonathan Ngubene, we are sorry to inform you we have no record of anyone of that name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's preposterous. I would have known -- of such a case... I mean... in my hospital. You people! You're always raking up trouble!

dialogues.speaker: J
dialogues.text: At the back of police headquarters, John Vorster Square. An elderly black cleaner, emptying garbage, is being shown Jonathan's photograph. He looks -- and nods -- pointing down as meaning the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is with a client.    He pushes a button on the interco LEWINSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Freda -- I said no calls... Oh... Right... put them through. Hallo! Yes! How are you?... that is correct. He listens -- his face slowly becoming solemn -- LEWINSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Thank you for finally letting us know. He replaces the receiver... looks at it for a long second ... before lifting his eyes to the client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to client)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. He dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea break for the teachers, Ben       among them. He is e ing a laugh with his colleagues       -- maybe in Afrikaa we should hear the language here       where we need not prehend. An African serves the        tea. There's a KNOCK -- a monitor comes in and talks to Ben who follows him outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben at the phone. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Dan... No... it's all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEWINSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. They have just officially informed me. The boy was never in detention. He died ... the day of the riots and as nobody came to claim the corpse he was buried a month ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, Dan... I'll tell Gordon. 'Bye. Ben hangs up and stays there... thinking... until the BELL snaps him out of his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The playing fields, not of Eton but as good as... ... Cries and whistles rise through the still, warm air from a game of schoolboy rugby being played below us by immaculately-fitted teams. On another part of the field Gordon's lawnmower off to the side -- two figures pace -- slowly -- one white, one black -- A VOICE overlays all this... strange... ironically African.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Ben, sir. If it was me, all right. And if it was Emily, all right. We are not young. But he's out child. My time and your time, it's passing. But the time of our children is coming. And now if they kill our children -- if we let them -- what is it that we lived for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (places a hand on Gordon's shoulder -- comforting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do, Gordon? You or I... We can't change it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That day, Mr. Ben, sir, when they whipped Jonathan, you also said we can do nothing. But if we had... if someone heard what we had to say this would not have happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a terrible thing, Gordon -- God knows I'm sorry. But you have other children to live for... I'll help them too with their schooling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he die, Mister Ben, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Gordon... He died on the day of the riots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what  they say. But I got to know for  certain. How can I have peace?   I must know how my son died and  where they buried him. The game on the next pitch finishes with a pierce of the whistle. The kids run off past Ben and Gordon. Gordon climbs onto the small lawn mower and STARTS the ENGINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon.   The police -- if they've said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what they say. He is my child. God is my witness today: I cannot stop before I know what happened and where he lies. His body belongs to Emily and me. And drives away -- chugging across the field... leaving Ben -- helpless -- behind him -- watching. From his:

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE WINDOW
dialogues.text: in the school behind -- a worried headmaster watches. We hear his voice over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... This business of Gordon's son. Be careful, Ben. These are not normal times -- one has to make allowances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car park. He and Ben are getting into their cars at the end of the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry! I'm no crusader. I've known Gordon a long time, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand -- it's your Christian duty to your neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't get too close. Teachers must stay out of politics. Love to Susan! And drives off, leaving Ben watching him, shaking his head at the man's obtuseness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily is watering a tiny vegetable plot in the yard, with a bucket and a pierced tin. Robert is playing nearby with the youngest child. Robert sees Gordon walking slowly to their house and says playfully to the baby:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who's coming? It's baba! Emily turns to look. She immediately realizes that some- thing is wrong. She drops the tin and walks a few steps toward the gate. Gordon sees her and stops. Emily starts to break down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no... oh no, Lord. Gordon hurries to embrace her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing and repeating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't tell me... Gordon starts to lead her to the house. Margaret, Emily's neighbor, comes, hurries, helps her, comforts her, escorting them to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley and Gordon are driving along Soweto main road. A 10-years-old BOY stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Stanley) Baba, I heard you're looking for Wellington. He's out, Baba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?   Where is he? BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's with some boys at Dube's shop. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. You've worked like a man. (turning to Gordon) Let's go. Stanley turns the car round and drives off at speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wellington and a few pals are standing outside the shop -- they greet Stanley as they see the car -- Stanley shouts back greeting. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, boys. Hey Wellington! Wellington comes to the car.   He's limping, wearing sunglasses. As he's approaching the car, Stanley opens the back door for him. He enters and removes the glasses. Stanley notices a deep scar from the forehead to the cheek. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened... Don't tell me... GORDON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they do that to you?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wellington has a nervous arm-twitch... and nods to the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know what happened to Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he out yet? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I last saw him weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to know how he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sizette and   Chris with the family at dinner. Suzette is passed the   Rand Daily Mail newspaper by Chris, folded a an article   headlined: "WHAT REALLY HAPPENED TO JONATHAN NGUBENE?"    by Melanie Bruwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that tragic? Jonathan was such a nice boy. Even played with my Johan when they were small, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he was such a nice boy, well- mannered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said he was very bright at school. Chris helps himself to more.     Suzette looks at the pap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this kind of journalism doesn't help the situation. Look at her face? What does she look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rand Daily Mail always exaggerates.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She passes the paper to Ben. He looks at Melanie's pic- ture: she looks 30 years old, long black hair, large dark eyes with a fierce, unsettling, uncompromising stare a small nose and a generous and sensual mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks quite attractive to me. Chris and Johan laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he surveys the article; then with a serious tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '... Is only the latest in scores of black youths who have disappeared whilst in police custody.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she expect? They're out of control. Give then an inch and they take a hundred miles. It's in their nature. The only language they understand is force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, Jonathan was fifteen, like me. Would you use force on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a terrorist. If you were -- like an increasing number of them, you'd deserve it. Look, every time you pick up the newspaper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts; focusing on the paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, one hundred shot! They didn't have to kill them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This bloody Bruwer woman reports one hundred shot, but the radio said only twenty and the police were attacked first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the idea was to give them their own areas, banstustans. Let them live with their own kind. No chance of conflict then. Everybody's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who would do the work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The work, who'd do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You for a start. Come on!    Help me clear these dishes. As Johan stands, to clear the table. He turns to his father with a smile, and shrugs -- an irritated Suzette joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small dark room is crowded. The one oil lamp -- on the table -- At the table sits Gordon... his glasses on the end of his nose. Emily is sitting by the stove.      Robert stands beside chair, watching, listening. The youngsters are sleeping in opposite directions on the iron bed. Wellington is sitting beside Gordon at the table. There is something wild in his manner. He looks everywhere as if he is scared of being attacked unawares. The black cleaner from John Vorster Sq. stands near the table. Gordon is reading aloud from a handwritten document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'On the second day of our detention at John Vorster Square we were taken to one of the top floors. We were ordered to undress and they started to beat us with fists and sjamboks. This for a long time.' Wellington nods and gets more paranoid. The black cleaner puts an understanding hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'On one day me and Jonathan...' Gordon pauses... steadies himself... pushes his glasses up his nose... clears his throat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '... We were asked questions for the whole day and night by Capt. Stolz and different policemen -- they never stopped. They tried to force us to say we were the leaders at our school, that we were working for the A.N.C. and got money from overseas. Capt. Stolz wanted to know the names of the students committee and where he can find Toni Mtimkulu -- Everytime they asked question, they beat us. It was bad beating.' Wellington nods again.    Emily closes her eyes to shut o the image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'We told them we had done nothing and didn't know about all the things they are asking us; on two occasion they put a wet bag over my head and I -- couldn't breathe -- I thought I was going to die. One day I heard Jonathan being beaten. He was screaming and crying, and then a noise like tables and chairs being knocked down, and Capt. Stolz shouting "you bastard, get up, do you hear me?" Ngubene, don't pretend here, get up." Then the next day I heard he had gone to hospital and I never saw him again.' There's a long silence. Gordon closes his eyes and struggles with his grief. Emily sobs, Robert looks on in anger. Then, finally, Gordon offers a pen to Wellington, who is about to sign the foot of the state- ment, when... ... Suddenly there   is the sound of a TRUCK APPROACHING. Wellington rushes   to the front window and peers outside then panics, fear   in his eyes, he runs into a bedroom a jumps through the   window. Everyone in the room is bewildered. The front door bursts open. Emily sits impassively look- ing at the five policemen (two whites and three Africans) The youngest child startled from his sleep starts to cry. Emily goes to the bed and picks the child up and returns to her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay right where you are. He notices the papers on the table and picks them up. looks at them and realizes their importance. Capt. Stolz walks into the room and surveys the room and its occupants. Lieutenant Venter hands him the papers. He goes through them, nodding to himself as he reads silently. He folds them neatly and puts them into his inside jacket pocket. He walks up to Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gordon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your feet! So, you must be Gordon Ngubene? Gordon doesn't answer. He turns to the cleaner who automatically stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know each other, don't we? Calmly, he paces round the room looking around, then when he reaches the bed where the 10-years-old girl is watch- ing terrified, he pulls off the blankets, yanks the girl off the bed by her arm and frantically searches the bed. The child cries. Robert the brother goes to his sister and hugs her as he glares at Stolz with anger and hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Venter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gert, in daardie kammer. (Gert, that room) (turning to the other one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaimie, in die ander. (Jamie, the other room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niks, Kaptein. (Nothing, Captain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the bastards away. The other policeman appears from the other bedrooms empty handed. Gordon and the cleaner are roughly handled as they are handcuffed by the African Security Police. Over his shoulder Gordon manages to give Emily one last look, as he's hustled out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Emily sits motionless, anger in her face.    She can hear the sound of the CARS DRIVING AWAY. Margaret (her neighbor) appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Ben's house, are the servants' quarters attached to the garage. Ben has adapted what would have been a maid's room into his study and the adjoining room into a do-it-yourself workshop. The study has photographs of Ben's past as a provincial rugby player, of his family, school staff and TRECHIKOFF reproduction. On a cupboard are trophies of individual sports at university. He works off a plain desk on which is a handsome pipe- rack with several pipes. His indulgence is a comfortable easy chair. Ben's study, containing only the figure of Ben. He's hunched over his desk, looking blankly at the newspaper. His shirt is unbuttoned, his jacket slung across his chair. He draws heavily on his pipe, wreathing his head with smoke in the beam of the single desk light. He sits in his chair: Gordon's voice rises in his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That day, Mister Ben, sir, when they whipped Jonathan, you also said we can do nothing. God as my witness today: I must know what happened and where he lies. His body belongs to Emily and me. He mutters -- more a prayer than a curse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeezus -- Jeezus -- Jeezus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Papa!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Johan is entering, knocking on the half-open door. He's in his pajamas and dressing gown, ready for bed. Ben looks up at him. Johan kisses his father who suddenly clasp his son hard, clinging to him for dear life. The boy throws his arms around his dad's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Papa! Susan appears at the door with a cup of coffee. She's had a bath -- her hair is wet -- and she's in her housecoat. Ben and Johan don't notice her approach. She watches sympathetically for a moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee!   Come on, Johan.   Time for bed. Johan pulls back from his father's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, son.   Go and get some sleep. The boy nods and leaves. As Susan rests the cup of coffee on the desk before Ben. She notices the Rand Daily Mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm proud of you, Ben... what you've done for that family. But darling, you shouldn't take these things to heart so much. What more can you do about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    I'm just tired, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stroking his hair gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come to bed. Her housecoat has fallen open.       He lifts his face to and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, in a minute. I'll just put the thoughts of Standar Six away. They mustn't be lost to posterity.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She chuckles, satisfied, leaving him. He picks up his cup and drinks. He thinks again for a moment. Then he removes a photocopied letter from an envelope and reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '... Seeking the whereabouts of a certain Jonathan Ngubene, regret to inform you we have no record of anyone of that name...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afrikaan boys in uniform hunching over their desks writing... On the blackboard: the date and history test: What year did the first white man arrive in South Africa? When was the Battle of Blood River? Who was the Zulu chief who was defeated at the battle of Isanadlawana? Who was the president of the first Afrikander Republic? Give the route of the Voortrekkers from the cape? Ben walks through the aisles and from time to time oppor- tunities to glance at the window at Gordon's motionless tractor sitting in the field. He turns back   and notices a boy focusing on the ceiling His pen in his   mouth, trying desperately to find the answers. Ben    has a smile, then crosses to him, bends d and strikes a   similar pose. The class breaks up into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping the student's back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, time up! Hand in your test. Moans from the students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben appears on the other side of the veranda. He is in Cloete's company -- the little big man... grey hair... 65 years old. The headmaster. They stop in before Ben's colleague, Vivier, passing, shakes hands with him. A woman arrives and waits. Cloete says something to Ben, then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ben smiles and Cloete goes into the office. The woman approaches Ben... talks to him... they both tur back to see... ... Emily standing there, a soaking headscarf tied native style around her head. Ben thanks the woman and crosses the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened, Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Baas... but it's Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Stanley is waiting in his car.     His sunglasses on nose... ... The SCHOOL BELL RINGS to give the end of the tea inte val. Ben walks out with Emily to Stanley's car. Stanley gets out, they stare at each other. Finally Stanley breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting out his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it? I'm Stanley! I heard about you! Ben feels a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Stanley Makhaya... He helps us all the time. Stanley opens the door to Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry too much, Emily, I'm sure Gordon will be home in a few days. Stanley slaps the door with a big laugh.     He gets into car and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon stands facing the wall, his arm raised.    He has wetted his trousers. Captain Stolz is pacing behind him. Lieutenant Venter, sitting on the edge of the desk, is smoking. STOLZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Kaffir, talk! GORDON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I've done nothing.   All I tried to do was to find... Stolz interrupts him with a blow to his face.    As Gordo drops his hands, the officer shouts to him. LIEUTENANT VENTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up with those bloody arms! STOLZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't like gramophone records here! Now who has been giving you informations? Gordon doesn't answer. The Lieutenant walks slowly to him, calmly removes his fag-end of cigarette from his lips and stubs it on Gordon's neck. LIEUTENANT VENTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very calmly) Why don't you answer the Captain, han? He walks back to his place. Captain Stolz opens the door and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johannes!    The bag! Gordon has a look of terror. Immediately a black security policeman walks in with a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Johannes goes to wet the bag in a bucket in a corner. Lieutenant Venter grabs Gordon, throws him onto a chair and handcuffs his hands behind the chair.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stolz is supervising. The Lieutenant places the wet bag over Gordon's head and ties it. Gordon starts groaning and wriggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the gaze of a uniformed POLICEMAN in a bulletproof glass cage, Ben fills in a slip, then hands it to the Policeman, who then makes a phone call. Whilst waiting, Ben notices a video surveillance camera. Just then, a 20-year-old African girl, Afro-style hair, is brought in held on both sides by two white policemen. She is taken into a lift. Ben watches them enter the lift and follows the progress of lift to the 10th floor. The Policeman stamps the slip and gives it to Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody will meet you on second floor. Ben enters a lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon's still sitting on the chair, slumped -- Johannes removes the handcuffs as the Lieutenant removes the wet bag. Gordon is breathing heavily and semi-conscious. Suddenly Captain Stolz punches him heavily on the face. Gordon drops on the floor with blood gushing from his nos and mouth. Captain Stolz grabs him by his collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on you bloody black bastard. Who has been telling you lies? The PHONE RINGS.    Stolz drops Gordon and walks to answe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be down immediately, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the large desk, Colonel VILJEON replaces the tele- phone receiver; there is a KNOCK on the door -- and a you policeman ushers in Ben. Colonel Viljoen stands and ex- tends a hand. VILJOEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Mr. Du Toit, come in. How do you do? They shake.   He's a large, friendly man, ruddy face, gra crew cut. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Colonel Viljoen. VILJOEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to watch you play for the Transvaal. You were one of the great wing forwards. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Long time ago. There's a KNOCK on the door. VILJOEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. The door opens revealing Captain Stolz. VILJOEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Stolz, Mr. Du Toit. Captain Stolz nods correctly, unsmiling, comfortably dressed, English-style. He shakes hands with Ben. Then walks toward the window and stands there. As he's watching Ben, he begins to clean out his pipe wit a silver penknife; VILJOEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben) Do sit down. Ben sinks into a low leather chair before the desk.    Be hind him he can feel Stolz's eyes. Viljoen peers through his half-moons at the letter in front of him. The pipe scraping continues behind Ben's ear. VILJOEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right now, Gordon Ngubene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... to put it simply, Colonel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always grateful for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought there might have been some kind of misunderstanding I could help straighten out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know him, Colonel. He works at my school. He's done work for me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you feel you know him enough to vouch for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, after so many years... 10 years. Gordon's not the type to get himself in trouble. He's an honest, hard-working, church- going man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! You'd be surprised how many honest, decent, church-going men we come across during a working day. He leans back comfortably in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's routine, Mr. Du Toit -- a routine enquiry. Cleaning up these townships we must leave no stone unturned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate that -- but Gordon would never...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an easy task either -- the press screaming blue murder -- especially the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they'll be the first to squeal if the Reds took over, make no mistake. Rushing back overseas clutching their bloody British passports. Have you any idea what will happen here if we don't follow every lead? We have a duty -- obligation. You have your job -- we have ours. Ben hastens to reassure him. He looks directly at Ben, frank, open, trustworthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel -- believe me, I'm with you all the way. But in this case -- I'm sure that in your worthy pursuit of the guilty you have, unwittingly, involved the innocent. After all, we're all human. We all make mistakes sometimes. Viljoen laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are indeed, Mr. Du Toit -- we are indeed. Though there's many who might need persuading as to that fact. Then... authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Du Toit. While you're here, would you mind if I asked you a few questions about Ngubene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, I'd welcome it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! There's another pause. The Colonel takes out a fountain pen -- unscrews it -- and arranges a sheet before him before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we start with his son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eldest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   He died some time ago. Viljoen doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about Gordon's activities since Jonathan's death? The noise stops behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Gordon ever discuss the death with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he did -- he was upset. The Colonel pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he accepted the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a religious man... in the end he would have resigned himself to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would have? You mean he didn't? Was he angry? Rebellious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Colonel! If one of your kids died... (nods to family picture on desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and nobody would tell you how it happened or where his body is buried, wouldn't you be upset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We told him how his son died, Mr. Du Toit.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ben turns back, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a son, Mr. Du Toit? The Colonel looks up at him... the first sign of steel in his eyes... then back to the papers. The noise starts again behind Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he burn and destroy -- everything he can lay his hands on?... No -- and neither does mine. That's what I can't understand... after everything the government does for them. (looks straight at Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it, Mr. Du Toit. We're for you, not against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never doubted it, Colonel. It's you who appear to be doubting me. These questions.   You're making me feel like a criminal. There's a moment's pause -- then a burst of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Du Toit... I'm sorry. It's force of habit. Once a policeman, always a policeman, eh? More laughter -- Ben joins in.    Viljoen stands, signall an end to the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johan is sitting, waiting, in the parked car... the RADIO ON. He's bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... As soon as we're satisfied he's innocent, he will be released. We know what we're doing, Mr. Du Toit. You want your wife and that boy of yours to sleep safe tonight, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ben nods, smiles, makes for the door, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One last favor, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon's wife -- she's very worried. May she bring him some food and a change of clothes while he's still here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem!    Thank you for your help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.    I'll rely on you, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you find your way out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. And thanks.    I feel much happier now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! And give my regards to your father-in-law -- tell him we'll have a drink sometime -- maybe go to a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.   Goodbye. And the door shuts behind him. There's silence for a moment... Viljoen staring at the closed door -- Stolz looks expectantly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the little bird singing yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Stolz leaves, shutting the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben opening his car. Johan is sitting in the front seat. As Ben gets into the car, he glances at the John Vorster Square building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is motoring through and out of Johannesburg.    Johan is silent beside him, impatient. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to them. Gordon will be released soon. The colonel was very understanding. JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see Gordon? Ben suddenly realizes that he didn't ask to see Gordon. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) No. JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they say anything about Jonathan? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but... Johan, he is dead. We can't do anything for him. Don't mention this visit to your mother. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette and Susan in the kitchen arranging the dessert tray. The kitchen is surprisingly neat. LAUGHTER is coming from the dining room. SUZETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What extra-mural interest? SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Champion of political detainees! Ben comes in to open extra bottles of wine, hears Susan's line. SUZETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing, turns to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right, Papa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Suzette. But, only one detainee: 'Gordon!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disbelieving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God. What on earth for? Susan leaves the kitchen without a word, with the dessert plates on the tray to the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan reaches VIVIERS and the minister DOMINEE BESTER, with their dessert plates. The candles have burned down amid the detritus of dinner: glasses disarranged and dirty, the cloth spotted with food and wine and ashes. In addition to Viviers, dateless, and Bester and his wife, the school's headmaster, Cloete and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben hastily uncorking a bottle of wine while talking to Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be a mistake, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is. I went down there, told them. They're looking into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went down where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Vorster Square. Suzette giggles, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You old devil you. Does Ma know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. And you're not going to tell her.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A pause.   She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful. I don't want my favorite Papa in trouble, Gordon or no Gordon. She ruffles his hair, smiles, kisses him.       They go b into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More wine?   Viviers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me, Oom Ben. I'm drunk enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cloete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Ben serves her. Susan passes to fetch milk jug and sugar basin from the chine cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Bester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I saw those sheets you liked, Sally, on sale at Bloom's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be free on Wednesday afternoon? I have one or two other things to buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan enters the kitchen. As she is about to place the jug and basin on the table next to the tray with cups of the same set, there is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. The door opens and Stanley steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and guests hear Susan. Ben jumps up, hurries to the door.    Viviers starts to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben stops at the door, sees Stanley, turns to Viviers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. Viviers returns to his seat as Ben shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you... hum... Stanley, isn't it? (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, darling. Ben leads Stanley out of the kitchen, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewinson is at the phone, behind him his wife, too, is entertaining guests for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Friday night, man! I'm no doctor, I'm not on standby all the bloody time. Can't they wait 'til Monday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan! I'm standing here with Gordon's clothing in my hand. It's bloodstained...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are broken teeth in the pocket. Monday may be too late! (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lawyer has been banned. Stanley is waiting, his great hand on his hips, the other one on Emily's shoulder. She is sitting on a chair. Obviously, Stanley doesn't expect a positive response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean Julius Nqakula? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad, he's a good lawyer. Why are you getting so involved, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to help Gordon. ... You represented many cases, tell me, does this happen often? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Gordon's not political. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Dan, I'm sorry for disturbing your weekend. Ben replaces the phone.    Turns to Emily and Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He agrees to see you tomorrow and will apply to the supreme court for an interdict to stop any assaults on Gordon. And, we'll find out what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all right, Lanie. Ben can just hear Emily's soft voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Baas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, sisi. Tomorrow it'll all be first-class again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter again. Ben has rejoined the party in the lounge. The women are together talking, laughing and the men on their own. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More coffee, anyone? General assent. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The security police don't arrest people for nothing, Ben. Leave it alone. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could make a mistake. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blacks lead double lives. One you see and one you don't. These people surprise you all the time. VIVIERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking) That's what I like about them. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not concerned with 'blacks.' We're talking about GORDON. A good man and very loyal. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (serving coffee to Cloete)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a hard worker too. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hard worker? I had to get rid of him. Susan doesn't react.   She leaves to join the womens' group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fired him a few days before he was arrested for staying away from work for days. And for the sake of the school I say good riddance. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean 'good riddance'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a responsibility for the children. These are troubled times, Ben, we can't trust the natives any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to be extra careful about any influences, Oom Ben. Even their churches are breeding grounds for all sorts of evil ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon's not subversive and definitely not a Communist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he's got nothing to worry about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except his three teeth. Our government mustn't allow such things to happen. After all, it's a Christian government. (turning to Bester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say, Dominee? Bester doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about the government! I believe in our government, damn it... His sharp tone surprises everybody.    He quiets. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Look, I know the police often know more than we do. I'm not questioning that. I'm as loyal as the next man. But I do know Gordon Ngubene... there is something wrong. There's a moment's embarrassed silence, broken by Suzette entrance with a tray of glasses and a bottle of brandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting the tray in front of Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else, Papa?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ben starts pouring, and offers the first glass to Bester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dominee? Bester shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nee Dankie. Ben hands the glass to Viviers. Immediately Viviers raises his glass and laughingly says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oom, Ben, may your problems be small ones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon is undoing his trousers. Venter roughly drops the trousers and pushing him to the floor. He handcuffs him while Johannes pulls off the trousers and underpants, and manacles his ankles. Johannes fetches a rod. Venter goes to a cupboard, pulls out two electric wires with electrodes attachments and places them on the desk. All the preparation is done with practiced efficiency. From the adjoining room there are angry shouts of a woman. Venter and Johannes place the rod between Gordon's elbow- joints and the back of his knees. The door opens. Gordon has a look of terror on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. Captain Stolz enters carrying a thickish file under his arms, goes straight to the desk and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnannes, the table. Johannes moves the table in line with the desk. Lieutenant Venter and Johannes lift the trussed Gordon and the ends of the rod between the desk and table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a heavy shitface. Too much mealie porridge! Captain Stolz holds Gordon by the head and swings him lik a pendulum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel today?   Ready to fly? Very calmly Captain Stolz pulls out some papers from the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing one sheet of paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mister Ngubene, we know about this Wellington... and... (pointing another affidavit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We know about him... and him ... Now, we want the names of the others. And today you're going to tell us. The WOMAN in the next room SHOUTING louder than before -- that one is a real and tough activist --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody woman. (to Johannes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water! As Johannes is fetching the bucket of water.        Vente to the cupboard and stays there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Samson' is ready, Captain, shall I switch him on? Johannes empties the bucket over Gordon.     Stolz attach the terminal to Gordon's earlobes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Venter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Gert! Gordon is given a short burst of electric shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hai!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a small taste of 'Samson.' We have a whole day... A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Kom! A black policeman in uniform.       JOHNSON SEROKE, enter with a letter in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter for you, Captain. Stolz goes to take the letter and turns to place it on his desk. He notices Seroke still standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you bloody-well waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reply, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Seroke leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gordon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now about these affidavits who told you to collect them? The A.N.C.? Who recruited you? Gordon mumbles something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He bends forward to hear, and Gordon's swollen, puffy eyes hold his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about the A.N.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've had your chance.    Now you're going to shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to lieutenant in Afrikaans)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reg gert. (Okay, Gert) Gordon suddenly shakes violently and shouts repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hai!   Hai!   Hai!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dominee Bester is preaching from the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God created the whole human race so that they could occupy the entire earth. He decreed how long each nation should flourish, and what the boundaries of each territory should be. Our task is to preserve that creative diversity. Behind him, in his deacon's black tails, Ben listens with clasped hands. On the opposite side, another man is lis- tening, standing in the love of his family, Cloete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers and sisters, like our forebears, the Voortrekkers, who trekked into the wilderness preserve the Afrikanere way of life given to them by God. Today, we also live in times of great danger. Let not fear overcome you! Cling to the ways of justice and truth preserved by our leaders. So shall God be honored...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faces    of his friends scattered among the pews, Suz and Susan    listening intently, Johan beside her visibly bored, his    eyes wandering to the Cloete's daughter at the end of    the pew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... So shall the Afrikaner people flourish. The organ plays the opening notes to a hymn, the congre- gation rises and sings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben's garage/workshop -- the door is open. Ben and Johan are together building a strong desk for Johan. The RADIO offers MUSIC to keep them company.   Susan is confronting Ben. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me you'd been down to John Vorster Square? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference would it have made? SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your wife, damn it! She turns the RADIO DOWN, irritably. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to upset you. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upset me? It upsets me when you share your bloody secrets with a child! Johan is embarrassed. Ben glances at him. Johan shrugs and shakes his head "not me." Ben planes on. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben! Ben! Look at me for God sakes! (turns to Johan) Johan uit met jou! Johan leaves. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (posing down the plane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what? SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a good life. We may not have everything we might have had if... BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
