dialogues.text: (interrupts) ... If I'd been more ambitious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, what's happening? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it seems to me I don't know you. Ben looks at her. Her tone is panic, urgent. She looks afraid. He crosses over to her, takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening -- it's something I've never had to face -- deal with -- before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the gardener for God's sake, not one of the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be patient with me... When Gordon is free you'll have me all to yourself again... promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nuzzling into his chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben.    We're growing old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. One's as old as he feels. I feel young and very attractive. I can still do my duty. She smiles up at him, chuckles, and then they kiss. Johan interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling indulgently at Johan's interruption)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley's here, Papa. Johan leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, bloody hell!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Susan exclaims in angry frustration and flees. Stanley appears at the garage door.     He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? The news leaves Ben speechless.      Stanley continues in flat, emotionless tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bastards say he committed suicide... hanged himself. Ben, recovering from the shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicide... is that what they told Emily -- poor woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't tell her. She heard it on the radio like the rest of us. I contacted Lewinson immediately. He then rung the police to ask why Emily wasn't informed. Would you believe it, they said they were sorry, and they didn't know where to contact her. Ben walks slowly out of the garage in deep thoughts -- Stanley follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God! I never thought Gordon could commit suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you understand me? I said, they said he committed suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon wasn't a coward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts aggressively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean 'but'? What about Timol who they said had jumped from a top-floor window? What about Ngudle? What about Mosala? Joyi? Malele? They all died in that John Vorster Square. All suicide, eh? Ben stares at him. There is something like a strange silence between them. Ben is confused and Stanley is staring at him. Ben breaks this embarrassing mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything I can do to help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm his brother, man, we all are! We'll take care of everything. (with pride)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the African way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley, I'd like to see Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look for trouble, man. You know there are riots all over Soweto. You're out of it. Why don't you stay out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand?   I've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a mischievous smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to go? Of course, Lanie... the last farewell. But we have to be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley drives sportingly as he talks to Ben, seated in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We expected it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you talk like that!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy gets picked up by the S.B... he's part of history, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you had no hope, you didn't believe he'd be released?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope's a white word, Lanie... It's not hope we need. There's silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank God Emily has you to lean on, Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily is like my sister... We go back many years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you belong to the xhosa tribe too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am an African. That's all! (looking through the rear mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comprende?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am an African too! Stanley turns abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was fourteen before I wore shoes -- except for church... I grew up on a plaas miles from any town... watching sheep and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit! Next you'll have me believing we grew up in the same country, same laws, same freedom, same everything!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a tour guide)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are now about to leave the white jungle and entering the land of love and glory. The car approaches a huge perimeter notice:

dialogues.speaker: THE NECESSARY PERMIT IS ALLOWED..."
dialogues.text: Ben is driven into a different world; children playing in dirty streets, in wrecks of cars, open spaces devoid of vegetables, smoke from large rubbish dumps, burnt-out skeletons of buses, beer halls and buildings. Clusters of policemen in battle dress patrolling in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is Soweto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like an actor, with big expansive gesture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Land of love and glory, Lanie! (turning suddenly to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But watch out for the police and army. They're patrolling all the time. The car follows an isolated broken stretch of tarred road hill cluttered with rusty tins, cardboard containers, bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of young children playing under the blinding sun in a muddy ditch, notice the big painted butterfly on the hood of Stanley's car. They wave and scream at Stanley in their language and he screams back at them. Two little girls start running, heading toward the car. Stanley notices the red VW parked in a corner. He man- euvers and parks his car nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up, Lanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modern funeral parlor with its name painted on the side

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Stanley notices the two little girls with dusty smiling faces, standing there waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his pants' pockets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sweets today. I'm sorry, babies. The children give Stanley a coy disbelieving look as they watch him go with the "white man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the doorstep of the funeral parlor: Stanley and Ben run into a young woman coming out with a shoulder bag and a camera. The young woman and Stanley exchange a quick, friendly greeting -- it's MELANIE BRUWER, the Rand Daily reporter -- and keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Ben turns back for a moment. Her face seems familiar to him. He would like to talk to her, but there is no time. Stanley is already inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Stanley follow the proprietor who is expensively- dressed in a dark suit. Gordon's coffin stands as one of many in the room. Inside the casket, brass fittings, white satin, lies Gordon, incongruous, ludicrous in a black Sunday suit. His hands are crossed on his chest like the claws of a bird and his face, barely recognizable, is gray, the left side distorted, blackish purple. There are rough stitches of the postmortem across his skull and a scar on his lips. Stanley speaks in an African language to the undertaker. The man opens Gordon's shirt and reveals the bruised and battered chest.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stanley observes Ben who looks at the wounds with horror. Then another command from Stanley and the undertaker opens the shirt to the waist. Ben's ashen. Stanley thanks the man and turns to leave. Ben remains a minute. He shuts his eyes tightly. Now he saw it. Now he must believe it. He must accept that this battered corpse is Gordon. As he follows Stanley, he thanks the undertaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the "sunlight," the children's laughter and Stanley, hands in pockets, waiting for Ben by the car. The same two little girls approach Stanley who gives them some coins -- they run off happily. Ben is coming outside blinking in the glaring sunlight. Stanley glares at Ben, who is pale, shaken and silent. They get into the car in silence. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Ben) 'The living close the eyes of the dead. The dead open the eyes of the living.' Stanley starts the car. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, take me to Emily. Stanley looks at him. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we'd took one hell of a chance to get here, let's not push it. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really have to see her, Stanley. Stanley drives off. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (determined; looking through rearview mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said don't push it. I have to keep you alive. What's more the house is full of mourners.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They drive in silence... then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your thoughts now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. I know you came to see the body. What do you think now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exposed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I cannot think.   I'm confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You either believe what you saw or maybe you still prefer the government version.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Christ sake, just get off my back, Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   It was a simple question. Stanley turns his RADIO ON and BANTU MUSIC invades the car as it speeds away in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big brassy Dodge is threading its way through the leafy calm of the white suburb. The "Bantu" MUSIC is STILL PLAYING on the radio under Stanley's animated conversation with Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Lanie, when you run a taxi, especially a pirate taxi like me, you have eyes and ears everywhere. Even when a policeman farts in his bed you know. People want a reference book, a permit to stay in Soweto, a house, anything, we taxi drivers know the routes. I'll tell you something... A news bulletin in African language interrupts the music. Stanley listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hassiem has been picked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he? Stanley silently pulls up along the curb and comes to rest at Ben's gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hassiem is the doctor we got to represent Emily at Gordon's autopsy. We wanted the truth. Ben suddenly realizes the significances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would have testified.   Bloody hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smart move by your Boer brothers. They have silenced Hassiem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His report has to be important. We can only use what we have. Therefore, Lewinson must get a very good advocate. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only we could get   hold of this Hassiem's report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use? It's one big game and we blacks are merely spectators. Hey Lanie, can one be a spectator as he's being kicked around? He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a question of being spectators. The courts are impartial, the law is what matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quite seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you all say. I have to move man. Your neighbors! Now, be careful. They will put their marks on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Stanley takes an empty cigarette packet from his pocket, he writes on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find out! (handing the packet to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you need me. Don't give your name -- just say 'Lanie' phoned -- right? Ben gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now tomorrow at ten...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharp! At our smart liberal friend's office, yeh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. Stanley drives vigorously away. Ben walks slowly and thoughtfully towards his house. notices Susan watching him through the window. He slumps on a chair on the veranda as Susan comes out of the house followed by Johan -- they both stand slightly worried at his moroseness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to Soweto and saw Gordon's body. They have lied to me, my own people -- they killed him! I saw the body.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Johan looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, you're not a doctor. His death was announced officially. They wouldn't say anything unless they were certain of their facts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more animated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Facts? There's a doctor who participated at the autopsy.   A Doctor Hassiem and he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the Indian doctor who's been arrested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in the five o'clock news, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him, he represented Emily at the autopsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly desperate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, I'm sorry about Gordon's death, but please for all our sakes, forget about this whole thing. Let's get back to a normal life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brandy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always know what I need. Johan hurries into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Ben, I'm frightened. She turns and walks into the house, leaving Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large Soweto cemetery has scores of graves ready for burials. The chief mourners, Emily, Robert, his sister, Margaret, four relatives and Stanley are standing on either side of the PRIEST. Gordon's coffin is in the grave; several wreaths are on the side of the grave. There are about fifteen hundred mourners, and half are youths. There are several local reporters and overseas television reporters. The police are in attendance in large numbers at the edge of the crowd, some in battle dress and some with dogs. PRIEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I conclude, I have to say we are tired of making this journey every day, sometimes twice in one day, burying our children, and those, like our departed brother, Ngubene who were merely seeking the truth; and those who have been denounced by traitors amongst us; and those who have been brutally killed for no reason, yes I shall say it, by the police. Let those who rule this land of ours listen to the word of God; let them listen to our peaceful and just demands; let them be humble and go down on their knees and seek forgiveness, then listen to God. The crowd roars:   "Amanda!   Amanda!" The Priest starts a short hymn and the crowd joins in. At the end of the hymn. PRIEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will have a few words from Mr. Pilani our father and leader. The crowd starts singing a freedom song with arms raised. The funeral has now become a political demonstration. Mr. Pilani, who is a dignified, educated 70-years-old, walks slowly and waits beside the chief mourners. He is handed a loudspeaker.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A SENIOR POLICE OFFICER threads his way through the crowd, a loud hailer in his hand. As he reaches the grave he turns. The crowd is quiet. He says something to the Priest then addresses the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral is over. I order everyone to go home. This is not a political rally. I repeat, disperse. As though by signal the police start attacking the mourners with truncheons and dogs. There is pandemon- ium, women screaming, people falling into graves or covering in them. The Priest and Stanley lead Emily and the family away in the opposite direction. The press and television are recording the scene. The police start throwing tear gas canisters. There is no confrontation, the crowd is fleeing in all directions. One television cameraman is purposely pushed into a grave by a very young policeman, his round recordist is pulled up into the adjourning grave by the connecting cord. Melanie stands on a tombstone watching and making notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, Susan watching the main evening news bulletin on TV. On the screen a sequence of rioting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite repeated warnings young blacks attacked the police with rocks and petrol bombs. Five policemen were injured. Susan briefly glances at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several arrests were made. One youth was killed and five wounded. Follows the newscaster and then reports:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning there was a serious disturbance at the funeral of Gordon Ngubene. Susan leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detainee who committed suicide by hanging himself at John Vorster Square. An overseas television cameraman broke an arm during the disturbance. It's been reported that several people had been killed by a car-bomb in Belfast Northern Island... Ben turns OFF the TV and stays in his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley and Ben are driving in the outskirts of Johannesburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley drives seemingly alone at very high speeds, which he maintains through the streets of Soweto... using his horn to scatter people out of his way, to the anger and indulgence of others. The CAR SCREECHES to a halt outside Emily's house. Stanley gets out of the car and greets the startled neighbors... and acknowledges the friendly shouts of children. Stanley looks around, then goes back to the car, opens the back door, leans and says something. Suddenly, to everyone's astonishment, Ben crawls out of the car; Stanley hustles him into Emily's house. Stanley waves at the people, a sign of assurance, then closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben stands awkwardly for a moment, taking in the room and the people in it. He then walks over to Emily who is standing at the table. He goes to shake her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, Mr. Ben, sir. Eh, that's father Masonwane, our priest, and that's Margaret from next door. Ben nods at them.    Stanley sits himself down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his hand in greeting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mfundisi... (priest) ... Sisi! (sister)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please sit down. Take this chair, the other one is broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to disturb you. I've come to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she sits on the broken chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's good. What I want to know is why did they kill him. He didn't do them nothing. You know, Mr. Ben, sir, I washed his whole body for he was my husband. And I know a man who killed himself, he doesn't look like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master, you must understand she's still raw inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure. Robert walks in, looks at Ben and walks into his bedroom to fetch something, then as he's about to go out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, where are you manners today? Don't you greet visitors? Robert stops momentarily and looks at Ben with hostility and hurries out of the room banging the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for his rudeness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to understand what's happening to our children today, they're like wasps when you burn their nest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Our children are saying 'that's enough!' Things have to change in this country. They accuse us of being cowards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, I have really come to assure you that I will do all I can to help you find out what really happened to Jonathan and your husband -- we cannot bring them back to life, but we can make sure that this sort of thing won't ever happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean well, sir, but it's better to forgive. If we keep the pain alive then hate and bitterness will remain with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air must be cleared.   So we can breathe again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air can only be cleared if we forget about yesterday's thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ben is right. It's not that I want to go on with this thing because it's a bad thing that Jonathan died, that Gordon died that's hard enough to bear, but I can forgive it. But they covered Gordon's name with dirt and we must clean it up, else he'll never have peace in his grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must understand for us, suicide is a coward's way out, how do they say, it's a 'cop out.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon wasn't a coward and we'll prove that. We have a very good advocate for the inquest. His name is De Villiers. I have confidence in him and the truth will come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth must be known. They killed my husband who wouldn't hurt a fly and they killed Jonathan who was only a child...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those people who did it are sinful people who don't know what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He! Mfundisi, what are you saying now? You mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must help them. That's the only way. They need our help, not hate, but love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pity them and I ask the Lord to help me so I can learn to love them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's what you preach in your church you will soon be starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They covered his name with dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you afraid sis Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. In the end one grows tired of being afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen! Ben has been listening to the discussion with interest, this being the first time he has heard Africans talking seriously about their problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, Stanley and I will do all we can. As I said we have a good advocate. Everyone involved with Gordon's death will be questioned and all that's known regarding what happened in John Vorster Square will come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can anything come out of that John Vorster Square? Who there will say: 'Yes, we killed the boy and Gordon?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawyers ask questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't policemen lie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Ben, sir for what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pleased I came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben as he goes to the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, let me check the situation. He opens the door and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small group of youngsters are there, hands thrust into their pockets, hanging around in a stony silence. Robert is standing by the door. Stanley calls one of them and talks to him -- the boys look around and say something. As Stanley goes back to the door, passing Robert, he ruffles his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Robert)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. (then to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okey, dokey, but hurry. Ben hurries out of the room.       The children stare at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go to the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, on the floor man. Stanley opens the back door for Ben.     Who crouches on the floor. Some of the boys snicker and one bursts out laughing. As Stanley gets into the car he shouts at them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Kids, time to go home.   Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure 'bra' Stanley. Take it easy. Stanley drives off at speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley is driving, they have left Soweto.       Ben stil the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we still in Soweto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you look for yourself? Ben rises and sees that they're at least a mile out. is not amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you playing at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he bursts into loud laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precautions, Lanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exposing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me Lanie!   What does that mean anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not understand, Lanie. They drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Ben are in bed.    Susan is in Ben's arms, she relaxed and loving. Ben talks quietly and calmly. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I am without awareness. I have always cared about people, call it a social conscience. But my visit to Gordon's house made me experience another dimension of human conditions. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poverty, ja... BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I expected that. But listening to them talk made me realize that I did not know the blacks. Now I question my attitudes, my concerns as Ben, and complacence as a white person. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, I know your anxiety about the inquest. All will be cleared up, in a legal way, and you'll be back to your normal self. Now let's turn off the lights. Susan kisses Ben tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inquest of Gordon Ngubene... conducted by MAGISTRATE KLOPPER. In the witness box is DR. JANSEN, the state pathologist, giving evidence. Advocate DE VILLIERS is cross examining. DE VILLIERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Jansen, you are a state pathologist of many years standing and I have no doubt a well-qualified pathologist. Could you now please tell us what caused the death of the deceased? DR. JANSEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found that death had been caused by the application of force to the neck, consistent with hanging.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There's a vigorous reaction to this around the court, which gives us a chance to discover the crowd: In the white section of the public gallery are Ben and about eight other whites. The black section is filled to capacity with a few stand- ing. In the front row is sitting Stanley next to Margaret. At the entrance, a white policeman. In the press section are several reporters; amongst them Melanie Bruwer the Rand Daily Mail reporter. Colonel Viljoen and several policemen are sitting around the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are sure about the hanging? This pressure on the neck, could it also have been exerted in other ways?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could, but it is not for me to speculate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, Doctor. The list of injuries found on the body was horrifyingly long; bruises, swellings, abrasions, broken rib, lacerations, etc. How long before death do you estimate he received these injuries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't say exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roughly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some were fourteen to twenty days old, others three to four days and others even more recent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even more recent. I see. I understand you had a Dr. Hassiem present at the autopsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were two reports, ours and his. Did they tally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it was.   In most respects. ON Stanley listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it normal practice to have one report? Why did Dr. Hassiem decide to draw up a separate report? If he really co-signed yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for him to answer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would very much like to, Dr. Jansen, but he's been detained -- you know of course that he represented the Ngubene family. Thank you. There's a murmur around the court... Ben looks across at Viljoen who returns his gaze -- smiling.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HERZOG
dialogues.text: the police physician, giving evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Herzog, did you examine the deceased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, one day Captain Stolz called me in. The man had toothache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as I could tell -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't examine him thoroughly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I? The man was perfectly healthy, just complaining of toothache. I extracted three decayed teeth, and gave him aspirin for the pain... that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the captain or anyone else assist you during the examination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I cannot remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more aggressive and accusing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Herzog, tell us. Have you been intimidated by the Security Police or did you deliberately cooperate with them in playing their disgusting little game of hide-and-seek?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping up from his seat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I protest, Your Worship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advocate De Villiers, will you refrain from insinuations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doctor Herzog... I'm sure Gordon Ngubene was extremely grateful! Herzog's face is impassive. ON crowd reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advocate Louw? During the hubbub De Villiers and the state advocate trade places. The courtroom is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Worship. I'd like to call Captain Stolz. There's a buzz from the spectators as Captain Stolz walks up to the witness stand. He's given a Bible. ON Ben -- watches him.

dialogues.speaker: STOLZ
dialogues.text: In witness box, swearing in Afrikaans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a police officer stationed at John Vorster Square?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Your Worship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You arrested Gordon Ngubene. Could you describe what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acting on information we had received, I went to the house of the deceased, accompanied by Lieutenant Venter, Lieutenant Botha, and three native members of the security force. This was about 10 P.M. I informed Ngubene that he was under arrest under Article 6 of the Terrorism Act. He then became violent and resisted arrest. A certain force had to be applied to restrain him. ON Stanley listening. ON Ben listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found several incriminating documents. These pointed to his involvement with the A.N.C. and activities endangering the security of the state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Ben looking at Stolz, and shaking his head, bewildered LOUW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the deceased ever assaulted to your knowledge? STOLZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. He was always treated with courtesy and correctness. But, one time we had cause to use force against him. It was the day before his death. The deceased suddenly showed signs of aggression. He tried to jump through the open window of my office. He was acting like a mad man. It took six of my men to restrain him, and he had to be manacled hand and foot, for his own safety. But once he calmed down, he was ready to make a statement about his activities. The next morning we found him dead in his cell. MAGISTRATE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the statement in evidence? LOUW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Your Worship. It can't be disclosed in court without damaging our investigation, but I would like to offer into evidence a suicide note written by the deceased. Louw, taking it from his file on the table. Stanley and Margaret listening. LOUW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dear Captain. I prefer to die rather than betray any more of my friends. Amandla! Gordon Ngubene.' He hands it to the court clerk.   There's uproar at this. LOUW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Worship. MAGISTRATE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advocate De Villiers?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ben is disgusted. He looks about the court, as if seeking allies. His eyes meet Melanie's -- just for a second there's recognition -- then he returns to De Villiers. Advocate De Villiers cross-examining Captain Stolz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Worship. Captain Stolz, you said you treated the deceased always with courtesy and correctness, then how do you account for the injuries found on the body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes detainees deliberately injure themselves for propaganda purposes. The gallery screams its objections. Stanley leans forward and grins across the partition at Ben. The Magistrate warns the crowd. Finally the gallery quiets down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say he tried to jump out of the open window... Are there no bars to prevent such an act?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had been removed for repair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why did he wish to jump out? Because you were torturing him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't tortured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it was the toothache then. No reaction from Stolz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you seized incriminating documents at the deceased's home; can you produce them to see how subversive he was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Magistrate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those documents cannot be introduced as evidence, Your Worship, in view of the fact that state security is involved.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Magistrate makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put it to you, Captain -- that the only subversive activities the deceased had been involved in were his efforts to establish what happened to his son, Jonathan, allegedly shot during a riot, although several witnesses are prepared to testify that he died in detention one month later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I protest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This would support my case that an innocent man has died in your hands under highly questionable circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it please Your Worship... this unwarranted slur on the integrity of the special branch is unacceptable... and based, I may say, on allegations which are in any case irrelevant to the present inquest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on Louw)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the police are really interested in retaining an unsullied reputation, they should not object to the real facts being presented. Thank you, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real facts are being presented -- as the following affadivits prove. They are all by detainees -- who testify that they had all seen the deceased intermittently from the time of his detention -- to the time of his death -- and on all occasions he was in good health.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As the documents are passed to the Magistrate, they are scorned by De Villiers. Imperviously he requests:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust the signatories of these ... documents... are available to corroborate their evidence in person.

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT ON ARCHIBALD CHIGORIMBO
dialogues.text: Detainee in the witness box.    He swears in Zulu. De Villiers holds his signed affidavit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Archibald, when did you first meet Gordon Ngubene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at black crowd, then to De Villiers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw Gordon Ngubene. A sudden stillness in the court. ON Ben. ON Stanley. ON Melanie. ON Louw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying that you didn't sign this statement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I never met Mr. Ngubene... they forced me to sign. Captain Stolz, he hit me many times with a rubber hose... he said he would kill me 'less I signed... this... this is what he did to me. He pulls up his shirt -- his back is covered in bruises. The crowd cannot restrain itself any longer.     Ben is aghast by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Archibald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advocate Louw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you, Your Worship. As Archibald leaves the witness stand, held by a special branch officer, he raises his fist in salute and shouts to the crowd: "AMANDLA." The crowd responds: "Ngawethu." Ben looks at Archibald. He is very impressed by this strength in the prisoner's eyes. An officer   of the court shouts at the crowd: "silte in die koort"   (silence in court) -- bailiffs collar a few the loudest   protesters and pull them with brutality out of the   courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to town, wearily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May we put up the second signatory? Louw confers hurriedly with the prosecution officers, the turns back to the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Worship -- the other three signatories cannot appear for reasons of state security. He sits down, bland, examining his papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Worship, I'd like to recall Captain Stolz. As Captain Stolz returns to the stand he crosses Archibal being handcuffed by the S.B. officer. Ben watches him passing by the detainee, straight, im- passive without a look to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, you're still under oath -- you took Archibald's statement. Was it voluntary? I'm sure you'll say it was, then how did he come by the injuries on his back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fell down the stairs a few days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fell down the stairs. You should do something about those stairs, Captain, so many people fall on them. Thank you. The crowd laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Magistrate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Worship, may I be excused? I have to escort detainee Archibal back to John Vorster Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may, Captain, and thank you. (to the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this's a good moment to adjourn -- we'll reconvene at two thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, Margaret, Stanley and a man, are sitting outside the court eating fish and chips. There are various Africans sitting around for their lunch break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Dan Lewinson having a light lunch in a nearby cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (buoyant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De Villiers is making mincemeat of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very good. His cross- examination has got them rattled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obvious to anybody! The evidence is clear! (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see Archibal's back? He didn't have to tell the truth. Dan Lewinson's dry laugh catches in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Stolz is saying to him right now in his torture room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advocate De Villiers and a dignified Emily in the witness stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Stolz lied. My husband never fight the police when he was arrested. They were rough with him, pushing him and threatening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your husband's clothes were given to you, in what condition were they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was blood on them and in the back pocket I found three broken teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Mrs. Ngubene, you have seen the note that's said to have been written by your husband. Do you recognize the writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not how my husband writes. (strongly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never wrote that letter, they lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Ngubene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advocte Louw? He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facing the Magistrate and in firm voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed my husband and son.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON Ben, satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a policeman next to Viljoen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take the woman out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to call my last witness. Grace Nkosi. Grace's name is called. She is an attractive 20-years- old girl. As she passes by Ben, he watches her with concern; her face looks familiar. Of course he remembers having seen her at John Vorster Square the first time he went there to meet the colonel. GRACE NKOSI is the African girl the two security officers were lifted to the ten flour. He recognizes her. Grace Nkosi in the witness stand. She swears in Xhosa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you ever detained?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, at John Vorster Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell us what happened to you during that time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was interrogated by many special policemen, but mainly Captain Stolz and the one they call Venter. As they were searching somebody I know, they wanted me to tell them where that person was hidden. As I refuse to cooperate they beat me with a sjambok. After some time I fell and they kicked me in the face and stomach. ON Ben obviously shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spot blood and they try to make me lick it. Then Captain Stolz threw a wet towel and started twisting it around my neck... (she illustrates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... until I lost consciousness. They did this several time and the last one Captain Stolz said 'come on meid, speak up, or do you want to die like Gordon Ngubene?' A few days later I was released. ON Melanie taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Grace. That's all, Your Worship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising and looking at Grace for some seconds)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made that up. Say you made it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the truth. I have nothing more to say. Louw sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall adjourn until tomorrow morning. I'll hear the arguments and give the verdict. The crowd stands and starts to leave the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent black crowd; Emily, Margaret, Stanley anxiously awaiting the verdict. Today the public gallery is more crowded than before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish to thank both advocates for conducting this case without rancour and in the best traditions of the South African legal profession.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON Ben's face.    ON Dan Lewinson's face.   ON Viljoen an Stolz's faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have listened to all the evidence and the arguments. To begin with I have to say that there was no conclusive evidence offered to prove beyond doubt that members of the Security Police had been guilty of assault or any irregular conduct on the deceased. There were indications that Ngubene was aggressive and on more than one occasion had to be restrained with force. There was sufficient evidence to conclude that death had been caused by a trauma following pressure applied to the neck, consistent with hanging. Consequently, I find that Gordon Ngubene committed suicide by hanging himself and that on available evidence his death cannot be attributed to any act or omission or amounting to a criminal offense on the part of any person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viljoen and Stolz smiling, shaking hands with Advocate Louw in congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The predominantly black crowd obviously dissatisfied with the verdict, discussing it as it moves slowly towards the main entrance. In the crowd Stanley, Margaret and Emily controlled, dignified but obviously pained.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: totally depressed, walking up to Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben over noise of the discussion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, man. There's another day! Ben leans towards Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Emily. Several press photographers are taking pictures osten- sibly of Emily the widow. Stanley gently guides Emily out of the building. Ben, who is following, is besieged by the insistent reporters, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Mister Du Toit, how do you know Mrs. Ngubene?' 'Mister Du Toit, can you answer, is it true, he was a terrorist?' Ben tries to get through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Du Toit, what do you think of the verdict? Do you believe the police? Melanie appears, grabs Ben and pushes him away through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on, Melanie, I'm coming with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off. The press is still pursuing them. As Ben and Melanie reach Melanie's car:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My car is over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind your car. Let's get away from these vultures.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They get into the car and as they drive away, Melanie introduces herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I'm Melanie Bruwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously of the Rand Daily Mail. I read your article about Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten out of ten, Mr. Du Toit.      I know about you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do? Melanie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a mutual friend.    One Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember. The mortuary in Soweto... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The ambiguous Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley? No. Just careful. A big black rough uncut diamond. Don't be fooled by his happy-go- lucky attitude. There's much more to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He couldn't have given you a glowing report of me. (suddenly aggressive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought a cooling drink at my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bruwer, I'm not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise you. I'm not after an interview or anything like that. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really must go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mr. Du Toit, and you'll meet my darling father. She smiles again.    A disarming smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie drives into the yard. The house is an old Colonial style house amidst flowers, bushes and trees, a controlled wild garden. A figure is bent over a beehive. A large brimmed old hat with a net hides his head and features. Melanie stops the car in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing from the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is by the eucalyptus tree, on the left. That's old Bruwer. They get out of the car and walk towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you lived here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, about twenty-one years.   I love this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you, Melanie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Dad. I want you to meet a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anyone have a friend nowadays?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He straightens up and throws the net over his head and studies Ben. MR. BRUWER is seventy years old; an interesting face with a goatee beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Du toit, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like bees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing against them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful, I can see philosophy coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shut up. (to Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you about bees, and for that matter ants: a bee has a completely altruistic sense of purpose -- based on the common good. A course from which he cannot be deflected. Greed, ambition, they mean nothing to him. He lives solely to serve his fellow bee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about individuality, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the rub, my girl. There's the rub. One of these days I'll ask the bees. I'm sure they have the answer. Now, you two run along! He replaces his net and continues with the hive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drink, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been peeing too much this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they walk toward the house) That's my Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie and Ben enter the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bruwer living room is a profusion of piles of papers, of books on shelves, on tables, on the floor, paintings -- records, African sculptures. On the floor tangled lengths of flex leading from a record player to two voluminous speakers. A settee, a chess set. The furniture is old and well- used, dominated by a large leather club chair -- two big cats sleeping on it. It's civilized pandemonium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing to the room) Now you see in what environment I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: was spawned. Ben looks at the shelves and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please sit down, on that chair. (pointing to club chair) That's Dad's. Drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.   A...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts, mischievous) A brandy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at her surprised, then smiling) No thanks, a beer will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie goes into the kitchen leaving Ben. He cannot forget what he heard and what he saw in the court! She returns barefooted, with two beer mugs, and hands one to Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mugs are the few things that Dad brought from Germany. He studied philosophy in Tubingen and Berlin before the last war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they were German? Melanie sits, her legs propped up on the settee, hugging her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Du Toit, tell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, call me Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Ben, tell me, why are you so depressed? You really expect a different verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgruntled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask? Can you understand it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I understand it. What could they have. I'm not cynical. I'm only trying to be realistic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Miss Bruwer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Melanie, that's fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, do you believe in the notion of justice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never stop believing. But in this country I've learned it's pointless to look for it in certain situations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What use is a system if justice does not apply to all situations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. And you cannot fight for justice unless you know injustice very well. You've got to know your enemy first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a tall order: 'know injustice... know the enemy.' it seems I have a long haul ahead of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, Ben. You have already taken the first steps. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to South Africa! She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is sitting at the dressing table. She is applying cleansing cream to her face. She is relaxed. Ben is getting ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you enjoy the 'bobotie?' When I heard the verdict on the news I knew you'd be upset. (softer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to make you something special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, darling. A pause.     Susan starts to remove the cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad it's all over. You take things to heart too much. Ben comes and stands behind Susan -- looking at her throu the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to keep control of himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed Gordon -- first they kill Jonathan, and then him. How can they get away with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soothingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now come on, Ben. Gordon's death upset me, too. But the Magistrate had all the facts. He must know what he's doing, he's had years of experience. The case has run its course, and nobody can do anything more about it! It's all over and done with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not so sure about that, Susan! Susan swivels around and faces Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm damned well sure! It's over, Ben! You better get that into your head. Ben just stares at her with seething anger.       She sta and starts being hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teacher, always a bloody teacher. You never moved yourself for us. But for the blacks, oh yes. Whose side are you on, Ben? And I'm sick and tired of those natives coming here. Why don't you bloody well go and live in Soweto? Ben strides out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following and shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soweto! Then shuts the door behind him. Susan stands stupefied.    There's the sound of the SPARE ROOM DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is standing in the middle of the room, in the dark. On the wall behind him is a young Suzette's picture.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a few seconds, Ben moves slowly to the bed and sits on it still in deep thought. SLOW MOVE TO a:

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: And:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Saturday morning. A shopping center in a white suburb.      Ben goes into a newspaper shop. There are two children buying sweets and a woman leaving. The PROPRIETOR is an Afrikaner in his middle age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More meneer Van de Merwe. (Morning Mister Van de Merwe.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in offhand manner)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More meneer du Toit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our boys gave the Eastern province a thrashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Ben realizes that the man is not his usual conversational self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Ben goes to pick up an Afrikaans newspaper and the Rand Daily Mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking up to counter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a packet of tobacco and pipe cleaners. The man gets them and takes a note from Ben and gives him his change. By then a man is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow. As he walks out the other man turns around to watch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben walks    out of the shop. The newspaper under his arm A group of    three middle-aged women turn to look at him Ben didn't    see them. A little further on, he meets Mrs Coetzee.     He tries to greet her but she walks straight Further on, he notices two men obviously talking about him. Then a couple of boys on bikes snigger as they pass him. He begins to wonder what's it all about, and spontaneously checks his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Suzette sit there. Suzette's holding a news- paper -- the Ossewa -- Susan's thoughtful, her face is re and discomposed -- obviously she had cried. The PHONE RINGS but they deliberately ignore it. Ben appears with the newspapers under his arm, sees Suzette's sports car and hurries to join them. Suzette doesn't even give him a chance to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping up and showing the cover of Ossewa)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Papa, this is going too far! How could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that, Suzette? Ben takes the newspaper and looks at the cover. A picture of himself and Emily outside the courtroom. The two faces are close together with the notes: "EMILY NGUBENE, wife of native who died in detention, comforted by a friend of family, Mr. BEN DU TOIT." And in parenthesis "see page two." He throws the Ossewa on a chair and checks into the Rand Daily Mail. Inside there is a long article with Emily's picture, titled "the Face of Grief." Ben folds up the newspapers, and shakes his head. He suddenly realizes why the people reacted like that outsid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't stop to think of the family. Poor mother, how can she face anyone? And tomorrow is Sunday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen... Johan steps into the veranda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's everybody yelling about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You listen, Papa, just tell me, why? Recognizing his father in the photo, Johan has picked up the newspaper from the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think I specially arranged for the photographers to take that picture? And what's more it's distorted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's distorted about it? Your face is practically touching that meid's face, like you were about to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgruntled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette, pull yourself together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today the whole country has seen that photograph. We, your children, are going to suffer. At this very moment Chris is negotiating with the Provincial Council. Would you like to see them cancel it? You have no feeling, Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette! She leaves in rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conciliating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Papa done, anyway? If something happened to him, wouldn't you be upset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not enough, Johan, to throw myself into the garden boy's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That goes without saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to joke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be easier ways of getting your name in the paper. Before she can stop herself, Susan slaps him across the face, although not hard. Johan leaves without a word. She clutches her hand, shocked at having it against him. The PHONE starts to RING.    Susan runs out sobbing. Ben looks at her then walks into the living room to pick up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?... I don't know you and have nothing to say to you... No thank you for your advice! He puts the phone down.    The PHONE RINGS again.   Ben p it up and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's you, Viviers... I appreciate it... of course... Not yet... Any thank you. Tot siens. He replaces the receiver and is about to light his pipe when the PHONE RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Cloete...   I'd like to say... (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mr. Cloete, may I ask what on earth has the picture to do with politics?... I'm sorry Mr. Cloete, I have to go. He replaces the telephone and walks out of the house. The PHONE KEEPS RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farm is a typical transvaal farm covering thousands o acres.  In the distance there's a range of mountains. Several cattle are grazing, herded by a poorly-clad Afric and his son, aged 8 years. Bester and Ben are leaning on the wooden fence of the cattle kraal with calves penned in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything was examined in depth in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you read the papers, Dominee? Were you happy with what came to light? And is it the Magistrate's work to pretend that the facts which came to light didn't exist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it really facts, Ben? Just then the African "HERDBOY" walks up to them taking off his lattered greasy hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja?   What is it Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the Baas want me to bring the bull now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dankie, Baas. Tom hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought a bull last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Gordon. What they said about him, that he was plotting against the government -- is a downright lie. He was only doing what I would have done as a father; searching for his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one but God can see what's in our hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it presumptuous to pretend we can speak for someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you no faith in your fellow men, Dominee? Don't you love your neighbor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confronting Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, instead of criticizing blindly, don't you think we have reason to be proud of the judiciary we have?  suppose this had been Russia; what do you think would have happened then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use of reaching a court when a handful of people have all the power to decide what is going to be said in that court and by whom? The one man they allowed to speak for himself, that young Archibald Chigorimbo, didn't he immediately deny everything they forced him to say in his statement? And the girl who spoke of her own torture? CUSTOMER PAGE 99 MISSING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That did not refer to our situation in this South Africa. Do you know what I believe in, Dominee, that once in one's life, just once, one should have enough faith in something to risk everything for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One can gain the world and still lose one's soul. Tea must be ready. Bester and Ben walk towards the house still in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff is having coffee during morning break in the staff room. The room has several easy chairs, a table wit the morning newspapers on it. The walls have pictures of South African scenes. There are several conversations in Afrikaans.   This is t first morning since the photograph. Ben walks into the staff room. The conversations stop. Everyone looks at him with hostility. The teachers all place their cups on the table and quietly file out of the room. Ben pours himself a cup of coffee; as he takes his first sip, Cloete looks in, sees him. He walks in. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't mind us talking here. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind, Mr. Cloete. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come to the point. You can't imagine how shocked I was by that scandalous photograph in the Ossewa. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman lost her husband, she was shattered with grief. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Kaffir woman, Du Toit. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) I can't see that it makes any difference. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone color blind then? And what about the apartheid laws? Our first responsibility as teachers is the reputation of the school, the pupils entrusted to us. We have to be an example to them in and out of this school yard. Ben looks at him calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I had warned you about involving yourself with Kaffirs. Obviously you didn't heed my advice.  That's all I have to say for now. Cloete walks out of the room. Viviers hurries into the room, he is late for his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, Oom Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acknowledging greeting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viviers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring coffee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private coffee with Cloete? Ben picks up the copy of the Ossewa with the photograph and shows it to Viviers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben stops the car in the Bruwer driveway. From the driving seat he searches the garden for Bruwer. He walks up to the front door and knocks, but there's no reply. He goes 'round to the back and finds the old man on his knees weeding his vegetable garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Professor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie isn't home. You are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Du Toit. You have a nice vegetable garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the area or the produce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both.   What plants are these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the world coming to? It's herbs, can't you see? Thyme there, oregano over there, feunel next to the tomatoes, sage here and rosemary somewhere. Poor plants, they re not in their ideal soil or climate. Next time, I'll bring some soil from the mountain of Zeus. Perhaps the old man's holiness will do the trick. He throws down the small weeding-fork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, you are just the person to sample my greengage wine. I don't suppose you've ever tasted it? I'm sure I'm the only person in the country making greengage wine. He leads Ben to the two old chairs by the back wall. He enters the kitchen and returns with a bottle of greengage wine and two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he pours)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first bottle this year, and you don't have to tell me if you like it or not. Tell me, did you ever study philosophy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.   I've read a few books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a sip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad, in fact quite good. Now where was I... Oh, I was going to say after decades of philosophy, I find myself being forced back to the earth. Do you know, Ben, we're all living in the spell of abstractions. Hitler, apartheid, the great American dream, the lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Jesus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Misunderstood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to the wine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie has told me a little about you. It's not an easy road you have chosen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel I have no choice. Bruwer farts loudly, Ben is taken aback, but the Professor continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you have a choice. Damn it. One always has a choice. Only thank God you made the choice you did. But all I want to say is, keep your eyes open, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's encouraging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are both Boers, Ben. We know how hard our people worked to get a toehold on this land; it was a good life. Now look at the mess. It's all systems and no God! Sooner or later people start believing in their way of life as an absolute: unmutable, fundamental, a precondition. Saw it, with my own eyes in Germany, a nation running after an idea. Sieg heil, sieg heil. I left there thirty years ago because I couldn't take it any longer. And now I see it happening in my own country, step by step. Terrifyingly predictable. This sickness of the great abstraction. He farts and sips his greengage wine.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ben is so fascinated by the old man's conversation he didn't react. He is learning form his old Afrikaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you say is very interesting and important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take for example the way the government is handling the electorate; like a bloody donkey. Carrot in front and kick at the backside. The carrot is apartheid, Dogma. The kick is quite simply, fear. Black peril, red peril, whatever name you want to give it. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear can be a wonderful ally, Ben. I talk too much, I always do with younger people, they don't fall asleep to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We Afrikaners have to stop to turn a blind eye and look around us and at ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are right. We still have time. History should teach us about those who regarded themselves as the chosen people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up comforted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Bruwer, may I say I have needed to hear somebody say some of the things you said. I still have hope for our country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you lose that you have lost everything. I'll get back to the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell that hot-head daughter of mine that you came to see her. Ben takes his leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Dan Lewinson are sitting opposite, cups of coffee in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is absolutely no doubt that they were killed in custody. Those responsible must be punished, whoever they are, or whatever their rank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is laying our hands on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Dan, we lost at the inquest, what next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family can file a civil claim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that entail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To put it briefly, it means we have to have witnesses, affidavits and any information relating to the arrest and death of Gordon. We also need similar information on Jonathan. You see Ben, for example, Stolz figures in both cases. That's one link at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I have to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lunch time and the working population of Jo'burg has paused for lunch. Ben and Melanie are sitting at a table outside. The cafe is on the outskirts of a very affluent part of Johannesburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think you would want to have anything to do with me after that crap in the Ossewa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?   You didn't write it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a journalist, perhaps tarred with the same brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened? I can imagine. The family, the dominee, colleagues, neighbors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distorted photograph and a few poisoned words and meneer Du Toit is a leper. That's why I called on you the other day, I needed to talk to somebody rational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the compliment. But remember, you're an Afrikaner, you're one of them. In their eyes they regard you as the worst kind of traitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are an Afrikaner too, and your articles, in a liberal English paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
