dialogues.text: My mother was a foreigner, I'm not pure, wragte Afrikaner. They don't expect the same loyalty from me that they demand from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of loyalty? Blind loyalty. Until the deaths of Jonathan and Gordon, I gave all the loyalty I could give, laager loyalty. You know, Melanie, we Afrikaners have always lived in our laager, we have not seen what's beyond the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has it ever occurred to you that the Volk may be scared to leave the laager? That's the downfall of this country. So, where do you go from here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We carry on.   There has to be justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost at the inquest, so we pursue them in a civil action.    I consulted the attorney Dan Lewinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know each other well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Du Toit, if you knew what we're working with every day of our lives, and what we're up against, you would understand why we have to be so thorough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However you go about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand you're upset about having your house searched ... but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't thinking about myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about then, Mr. Du Toit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My thoughts, Captain, I'm sure, are an open book to you.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stolz picks up a book of Picasso's Peace Paintings, starts leafing through it carefully, scrutinizing each page. He puts the Picasso book carefully back in the place he took it from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An interesting book -- Picasso -- Not one I'm familiar with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not on your list of banned books, Captain? Stolz doesn't react...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The search continues in the living room.        Susan is standing pale, rigid, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Du Toit. If you're keeping anything from us, we can turn this whole house upside down if we want to. We have all the time in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing Ben a warning daggers look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't understand. Nothing from Stolz. One of the men starts to roll up the carpet to look under it. Susan has to move out of his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid she has to stay where we can see her -- in case she wanted to warn someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's an M.P.!   Warn who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four tires of Ben's car have been slashed to ribbons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Johan are there. Ben takes a file from under a toolbox and measures it carefully against the drawer base. Then, he selects a piece of wood approximately the size of the drawer and tries it for size. We should be in no doubt that's he's constructing a hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is preparing a roast. There's music from a trans- istor RADIO. Susan is startled by a voice, her father's (Ben's FATHER-IN-LAW). She turns OFF, the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roast beef, I hope it's like your mother's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa! He is aged about 70 years, thick set. She rushes to him and he hugs her tightly and practically lifts her off the floor. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mama? She disentangles herself and goes to the living room as excited as a child, the mother is standing by two cases, smiling. Susan hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama! She holds her mother at arm's length inspecting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The perfume and a new hairstyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father insisted that I don't disgrace you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hugging her again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expected you a little later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She insisted we start early. Where is Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking in with golf club bag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the study. I'll get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you put on weight, Susan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't say that, Papa. Ben walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.   Didn't hear you arrive. He shakes hands with Father-In-Law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. He goes to MOTHER-IN-LAW.        He kisses her on the che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how are you, Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Ben, still have trouble with my feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't everyone sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll prepare some tea.     I baked a cake. She goes to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LOCAL GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Ben and Father-In-Law are having a drink after a round of golf, outside the club house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting tired of the trek to Cape Town and then back to Pretoria. If I had my way, Parliament and government would be in the same city. There's nothing wrong with Pretoria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd prefer Cape Town; the sea and Table Mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for   holidays. Anyway, Ben, one of the   reasons for this visit was that I   wanted to have a discussion   with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that photograph in the papers. Ben, a thing like that could be an embarrassment for someone who is a member of Parliament. It's a grievous day when one's family's behavior comes between him and his duty to the fatherland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you blaming me for trying to help those people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing that all my life, be they black or white. But no member of our family has been seen with a Kaffir woman before, Ben. Father signals the African waiter for more drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am glad you mentioned it, Father. Because I'd like to discuss the whole thing with you. First, there's the matter of Gordon Ngubene himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him? I thought the case was closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inquest didn't clear up half of what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no irrefutable evidence yet, but we have enough to indicate that something serious is being covered up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're jumping to conclusions, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black waiter places the drinks on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Ben, I'm listening. Perhaps I can use my influence. But you'll have to convince me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they have really nothing to hide, why is the special branch going out of its way to intimidate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (practically choking) What's this about special branch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They raided the house; they are tapping my phone, and I have been threatened by one of the officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Ben, I'd rather not have anything to do with this sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the special branch are involved they must have good reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's exactly what I said, Father, when Jonathan first got into trouble. Of course, they have good reasons: hushing up how Gordon died and how his son died!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, how could you side with the enemies of your people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you're prepared to sit back and allow an injustice to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his face grows purple)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's you, Ben, who talk about injustice? A man who teaches history at school? Did you forget what our people have suffered under the English oppressors? Now that we have at along last come to power in our own land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're free to do to others what they used to do to us. What will you do if you were a black man in this country today, Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you realize what the government is doing for the blacks? It's a slow process, Ben. One of these days the whole bloody lot of them will be free and independent in their own parts of the land, the bantoustans -- what can be more just than that? But they're not ready yet. The waiter returns -- Father-in-law pays the bill, and as he rises to leave, he puts a paternal arm on Ben's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have nothing to be ashamed of before the eyes of the world, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing, his golf bag in his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't? I'm not sure we're going to survive. They walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't underestimate us, Ben.    Our power of survival. We are Afrikaners!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley is parked in a street corner in the last     whit suburb on the way to Soweto. Ben pulls up in his      car behind Stanley's. He walks over to Stanley's car      and enters the back. Stanley smiles as he points at      his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: African time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. They drive off towards Soweto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter, Lanie -- as long we are on time for the revolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The special branch searched my house four days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The S.B. searches your house? (chuckles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they take anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few journals, letters -- nothing much. Just wanted to scare me, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so sure. They may think you're onto something big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not that stupid.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stanley laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Lanie' -- don't you believe it -- nothing's as stupid as the old S.B. If they decide it's a bomb they're looking for, you can shove a turd in their face and they'll swear to God it's a bomb. He laughs... making Ben smile. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scare you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   They tried too hard. Stanley laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hallelujah! (offers his huge hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shake, man. Join the club. Ben accepts the handshake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan sitting on an armchair, sewing. She is aware of a car stopping opposite the house. Then several young voices shout: "Kaffir lover" "Kaffer boetie" "Red Communist" The car drives off at speed. Susan sits petrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Stanley driving in Soweto. It's a different city by night. The dark seems to soften the violence of the confrontation, hiding the details which, by day, assault and insult the eyes. There are several GUNSHOTS in the distance. The only light comes from the small, square windows of the innumerable houses. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that, Lanie?     More kids dying? Ben says nothing. Further on there's a group of people outside a house. they pass they hear HYMN SINGING from the house. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening?   What's the singing? STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wake for a child; eight months old. She was sleeping and they threw tear gas into it. They drive on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, Stanley and Emily are sitting    'round the table. B has pulled the lamp closer to read    one of two notes fr Gordon -- one is written on ruled    paper, the other a square of toilet paper. The notes     have been smuggled of John Vorster Square. GORDON (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakily) 'My dear wife, you must not worry about me. I miss you and the children. You must look after them in the fear of the Lord. I'm hungry, and I don't know what they want from me. But I think I'll be home some day. I think about...' They are interrupted by a KNOCK at the door. Emily snatches the notes and stuffs them into her bosom. Everyone is tense as Emily slowly walks up to the door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She opens it and   a man with a hat and dressed as a min- ister walks in.    Before anyone can say anything, Stanle bursts out in a   loud laugh. The man is slightly built, aged 40 years.    He is JULIUS NQAKULA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your knees, everyone, prayers time. Ben is perplexed.    Emily closes the door and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man, you should have been a mfundisi holiness oozer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (removing this hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Stanley. It's stupid, but one is forced to do these things. He walks up to Ben and offers him his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Julius Nqakula... I'm banned and also under house arrest. That's why I have this ridiculous garb on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's one of the most solid lawyers we have; they've immobilized him, that's the right word isn't it? He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley has told me about you. I appreciate the risk you are taking by coming here to meet me. I was reading the notes Gordon smuggled out of John Vorster Square...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a glance at them? Emily produces the notes. Julius takes them. He starts reading the toilet paper, which is harder to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking with great difficulty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'My dear wife. I am still in these conditions... worse... and too much pain. They don't want to believe me. You must try to help me. They won't stop. You must care for the children. I don't know anymore if I will come home alive. They're very -- (a word mumbled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but God will provide. I love you and I miss you very much. Try to help me because...' The voice breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Emily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you get the letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first one two days after they took him away. And the other one came later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Emily, why didn't you tell me long ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had given my word to the man -- who brought them to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily, I have to meet the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he didn't want anybody to know who he is. I cannot make trouble for him in his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has to be persuaded.   He is very important to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Julius)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You as a lawyer will understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We intend starting a civil suit against the police, to do that it is necessary to have as many affidavits as we can from people who have any information about Gordon since he was arrested. And this man is vital and so is the Indian doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Dr. Hassiem. How are you going to do that? You know of course that he is detained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, with luck they may release him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Emily, this man is important, please try to tell him we will protect his identity. No one will know. Nothing will be done without his approval. I only want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you leave it to Stanley and I? What do you say, Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I call you Julius, I'm not very good with some African names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nqakula, that's a hell of a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please call me Julius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This case must be reopened and we must win. We have to dig up everything. We need your cooperation, Julius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I start? Don't forget my restrictions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did not ban you so you could sit on your backside and have a Soweto holiday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could help with the affidavits. Lewinson the lawyer has stressed their importance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know each other. He's a good lawyer for this kind of case. Of course I'll do what I can. My commitment forces me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How   are you planning to safeguard the   documents? Stanley told me you   have already had a said by the   S.B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry.    I have a secure place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make some tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me, Sis -- too strong for me. No whisky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my house? You know better than that, Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea then... (turning to Julius)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and God forgive me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is standing by the workbench, the new drawer he and Johan built for the toolbox, open before him. He's rereading Gordon's letters to Emily. Sound of approaching FOOTSTEPS. Ben quickly puts the letters into the drawer and shuts it. Susan appears at the door -- she looks ten years older. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, it's Johan. You'd better come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johan sits, Ben crouched before him.   The boy's shirt is torn, his eyes swollen, his lip cut.   He looks at the floor. Susan hovers. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't tell me why it happened Ben holds his son's arms, gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johan.   Was it because of me? He doesn't answer for a moment.   Then he nods. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see! It's gone too far, Ben. You've got to stop it... JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting at his mother)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care! It doesn't hurt me! Susan stares at him, at Ben, turns abruptly, walks out of the room. Johan looks at his father. JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my friends, Dad. They're so stupid... They won't listen. They don't even want to know what you're trying to do. He's crying. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it worry you? Johan looks at his father through his tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop, Dad. You mustn't give up now! Ben hugs his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gordon Ngubene name-cleaning team on the move.

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: in a phone box dialing a number.

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: RINGING, RINGING, on a desk full of scattered files and papers. By the phone a photograph of a six- year-old Indian girl.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: Sound of the PHONE, a young nurse's frightened face as she remembers peering in at a young boy, struggling and moaning... Policemen closing the door...

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: her hand signing the affidavit and handing it to a man's hand.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: Ben in the phone box hanging up the phone with rage.

dialogues.speaker: F
dialogues.text: a young black man's face listening to Julius's voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And on the morning of the autopsy, as I was cleaning the mortuary, Captain Stolz gave me a bundle of Ngubene's and ordered me to burn them.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The young man nods.

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: having a look on the two affidavits before hiding them into the drawer of the stool box. SHOTS.     Three!    Loud, sharp, terrifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WINDOW, a    LAMP and a MIRROR SHATTER -- Susan screa standing, her    hands -- clamped over her ears -- eyes tight shut --    hysterical -- the TELEVISION CHATTERS on an Afrikaans'    play. Ben bursts in, holds her tight, as she screams into his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the police, Ben, call the police! Johan's voice comes from his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa!    Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, son... we're all right. Everything's okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, stay there, please!! Gently, he leads Susan who is sobbing now, out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in disbelief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God. They were trying to kill us. She's seated at the kitchen table. Ben has poured her a brandy which she cups in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were trying to scare us, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her fear turns into anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that all... What the hell more do you want to happen... we're ordinary people for God's sake -- and you've pitched us into this -- this nightmare. I can't take any more, Ben... I can't take any more!! She drops her head and sobs. Ben sits beside her, and takes her hands to comfort her. Susan puts her head on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a quiet pleading voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Ben, stop. Just stop... please. Ben is obviously moved. He squeezes her hands, then takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colonel, amiable, cool, behind his desk. A dishev- elled Ben, pitched angrily forward in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you must be exaggerating, Mr. Du Toit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My house has been searched. My phone is tapped. My mail is opened. And last night three shots were fired through my window -- close to killing my wife. Viljoen reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Du Toit, if shots were fired into your premises, we will investigate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I want to know, Colonel, is why don't you leave me in peace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait, wait a minute, Mr. Du Toit, you're not trying to blame me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Colonel, why is it so important to you people to stop my enquiries about Gordon Ngubene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you are doing? (he pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now. If you possess any information that may be of use to us, I trust you won't hesitate to discuss it with me. He leans forward towards Ben, his tone darkening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if there are facts you are deliberately hiding from us, Mr. Du Toit -- If you give us reason to believe that you may be involved in activities that may be dangerous to both yourself and us -- then I can foresee some problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a threat, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling and sitting back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's call it a warning. A friendly warning. For God's sake, open your eyes, Mr. Du Toit! Don't you see you're being used!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the Communists, I suppose. Ben gets up to go.    The colonel doesn't rise to see him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Colonel. (at the door, turning back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure. He leaves.    The colonel immediately picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 40-year-old African woman walks up to Ben's kitchen door. She knocks. Ben opens the door in pyjamas and dressing-gown.    She hands him a note and leaves. Ben reads the note and goes back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vrededorp is a colored section of Johannesburg. It's rundown area vacated by whites. There are children play- ing in the street. Some unemployed men are sitting on old chairs outside a doorway; a vendor is serving two women from his milk churn. Ben drives into the street   searching for an address. He stops outside a house. As    he gets out of the car the children and everyone stop   to look at him with interest He walks up to a door and   knocks. A COLORED WOMAN appears as the door opens.    She is youn and obviously educated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Du Toit? Ben nods, hesitatingly. COLORED WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, come in. Ben walks into the living/dining room. It's a    very tid room with a three piece sitting room suite, a   sideboard with a clock on it. At one end of the room is    the dini area. The floor is linoleum and covered with    a rug in the middle. Stanley is lounging on a settee, beer in hand. On the chair next to him a black man in a brown striped suit, drinks orange squash. Thirtyish, pleasant face but very tense. He rises as Ben walks in. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising and shaking hands with Ben)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it? No trouble finding this place? You met Sadie. She's one of us. Ben nods to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Johnson Seroke.    The man of the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding in greeting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please sit down, Mr. Du Toit. A beer, tea or orange squash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beer would be nice. Sadie goes to a cupboard and brings out a bottle of beer and a glass. She opens the beer and hands it to Ben. She disappears into the bedroom with a curtain at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know they call this place Vrededorp, but we baptize it Malay Camp. Your first time in Malay Camp, Lanie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've driven through here many times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main road, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja. The woman re-enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll excuse me. Stanley, you know what to do with the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Sadie. And thank you. Can I help myself to another beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it is. Goodbye, Mr. Du Toit, and you, be careful. To the Seroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Sadie. Sadie leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That woman can die for you. We mustn't be long, Johnson has to be back on duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, let's get on with it. Stanley tells me, you work at John Vorster Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no choice, they transferred me there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet you smuggled out letters to Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling the fingers of his left hand one by one cracking the joints over and over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do if a man asks you, and he's in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they find out he'd be in very big trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. Tell me, what do you know about Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did talk to him from time to time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave me the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you saw him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just before he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you attend any of the interrogations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not a member of the Special Branch. But once I had to deliver a letter to Capt. Stolz, Gordon was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How were they interrogating him? Seroke hesitates and looks at Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.   Tell him what you told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were using the pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pole, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They handcuff you and manacle your feet then they put a pole between your arms and the back of your knees. Then you're like a chicken ready for the oven. They hang you between two tables. Then they do what they like with you. The S.B. call it the aeroplane. Ben is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Who were in that room? Stolz...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Venter and a black S.B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very interesting. When was the last time you saw him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw them take the body away to the cells. He was limp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did! Johnson, why do you stay with the police? You don't really belong there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a job. And how can I go away? I love my family. He jumps up and faces Ben with a look of anger and panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must never know I told you anything. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.    I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is strictly between the three of us. Don't worry, man. Seroke shakes hands with them as he's leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping his back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. Stanley goes to the cupboard for another beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beer, Lanie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. You know, Stanley, after what happened the other night I was about to give this whole thing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intrigued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife nearly got killed. Three shots were fired into the house. What right have I to expose my family to harassment and actual physical danger? That's what I asked myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three bloody shots and you crawl on your hands and knees to people like Stolz, and say 'I give up.' What is the beginning for you is a version of what we suffer all our bloody life. Shit, I thought you had more guts than this, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say I'm giving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson has revived my determination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hell of a time, Lanie, but we'll survive. You and me. I tell you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think we may still win in the end, Stanley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, Lanie -- but we needn't lose either -- what matters is to stick around. Ben nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, man, I'm off on a trip -- Botswana -- thought I'd tell you in case you get worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you going there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business. Tell you next week. Now for the bad news I've been saving to the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julius has been arrested. He broke his banning order and visited his sister. You know what that means? At least a year's imprisonment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year in jail just for visiting his sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the chance he took. And he'll be the last to complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think the real reason for this arrest was that they found out he was helping us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? Lanie, you're not getting guilt complexes now, are you? That's a luxury only liberals can afford. Julius will be back, man. All refreshed by a spell in the deep-freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we shrug off a man we've been working with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said we're shrugging him off? Best way of remembering a man, Lanie, is to carry on fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben's study is in chaos. The books have been plucked from the shelves and the contents of his drawers emptied on the floor. Ben standing in the middle of the room surveying the vandalism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a medium-sized kitchen with two doors leading from it, one to the dining room and the other to the living room. It has not changed since it was furnished twenty years ago, the only modern appliances being the electric stove and a modern mixer on the working table. Ben is leaning against the wall next to the door leading to the living room, drinking coffee. Melanie, bare-feet, her long black hair tied up in a ribbon, is washing up. She looks younger and fragile with this hair-style. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) What about you? MELANIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean not married... MELANIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And living in this chaos with my eccentric father? I love him and we get on perfectly. We have been together since I was a year old. My mother could not adapt to South Africa. She went back to London and we've never heard from her since. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being a professor and bringing up a child, how did he manage that? MELANIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy, dear Dorothy, she was a fantastic mother. In fact she had two families, me and her three children in Alexandra township. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this little girl grew up to be a tough journalist. Why a journalist? MELANIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Sometimes I ask myself the same question. She leans against the sink and picks up her mug of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I'll tell you. I was brought up in a sheltered way, not that Dad was possessive, not openly anyway. I think he'd just seen enough of the mess the world was in, to want to protect me as much as he could. Then, I went to university. I don't know what you'll think... being a teacher. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I married my ex-teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   He must have been young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen years difference. He too protected me like Dad. Then one day I visited Dorothy in Alexandra and saw her home and the appalling conditions in that township. I was shocked, Ben, and ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Melanie pours him another mug of coffee and starts to wipe up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That made me think that I was a parasite, something white and maggot-like... just a thing... a sweet and ineffectual thing. I felt more and more claustrophobic. Poor Brian, who loved and pampered me. Had no idea what was happening. I left him for a whole year and we divorced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then you became a journalist? Melanie goes to the living room, as she passes Ben she touches his arm and continues talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it would force me, or help me, to expose myself. To force me to see and to take notice of what was happening around me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns to the kitchen with a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could give you a straight answer. What did help me was my wanderings in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you manage that on a South African passport? We South Africans are white devils in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother was English, remember? So I get a British passport. It comes in handy even for the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really are your father's daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what he's doing right now. Most likely standing on a rock, looking through his old binoculars at springbok or a lion or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the two large CATS approaches them, tail in the air, and goes to Melanie, drubbing against her legs, PURRING luxuriously. She picks it up into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often does he go on these trips to the veldt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends -- (approaching Ben with cat) -- Bonjour, Ben. I'm Porto and my friend is Bello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben smiles and starts to caress Porto in Melanie's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked outside the house is a municipality truck already half-laden with Emily's furniture and possessions. Four Africans in khaki overalls are loading the truck -- super vising the eviction of Emily are a white Soweto official, Captain Stolz and Lt. Venter. In the b.g., a hundred yard away is a "hippo" with black and white armed policemen. Behind the truck are two police Land Rovers. Emily is sitting outside on one of her chairs as neighbor walk up to her to comfort her and say their goodbyes. Her daughter is carrying the youngest child and standing next to Emily -- several children are watching. A woman in the crowd starts singing a freedom song: "UMZIMA LOMTHWALO" ("THIS BURDEN IS HEAVY"). The song is taken up by the other women. Venter tries to stop them and disperse them. Stolz signals to him to leave them alone. One of the Africans then walks up to her for the chair. She refuses to get off the chair. The man looks at the white official as though to ask "what do I do." The official looks at Stolz. Venter walks up to Emily and, about to pull her off the chair. EMILY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you touch me! Venter pulls back. The women start to ululate. Emily rises majestically, takes the youngest in her arms and walks slowly to the truck followed by her daughter. People cluster around her, singing with rage and shaking her hand. Stolz observes the scene, impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back!    Buya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buya!   Buya! Emily and the children are helped onto the back of the truck which drives away preceded by the police "hippo" an escorted from the rear by the Land Rovers. The crowd continues singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is leaving his home. This is a Saturday morning. Two men are sitting in a car a few yards from the entrance to the house. Ben doesn't pay attention to them. When he is about twenty yards past, one of the men, Jaimie -- who was present when Gordon was arrested -- gets out of the car and follows Ben. Ben stops at a corner for a car and again the FOOTSTEPS stop.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns furtively and sees the man, stopped, turning his head. Ben decides to turn the corner, and listens to the FOOTSTEPS. The man is still following. Ben then decides to turn right back to have a good look at the man. They pass each other and Ben takes a good look at him and turn back onto the streets to the local shops. The man decides not to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Stanley sit. Ben on his desk. Stanley in an armchair with a drink. They look perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a widow, man. That's what happens in Soweto when a woman loses her man. They throw her out of the house and out of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zululand! The whole thing smells of being an excuse to send her hundreds of miles from the case. And how will they live there?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! I was about to find her a place, but I had to go to look for Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, that's why you went to Botswana for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sis Emily asked me but it was no use. His mind was made up. He was going to join Wellington in Zambia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't you stop him?   He's a little boy, Stanley! Stanley gulps down his whisky and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (focusing Ben in the eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be back in a few years.     And he won't be throwing stones! Then, puts the empty glass on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley peers through the curtains: he sees a car parked outside the house. In it Jaimie and another S.B. They are watching the house. Stanley quietly opens the door and walks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley walks past his car and approaches the policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (using his usual humor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. I'd like to invite you into my humble home, but it's full of terrorists. The two policemen get out of their car, obviously angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at Stanley's car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the boot! You cheeky bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, with pleasure. They search and find nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the door and remove the seat. Stanley executes the order. Jaimie and the OTHER POLICE- MAN peer in, their eyes sweeping the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, your pass, bliksem. Stanley   produces his passbook and hands it to the Polic man who   inspects the pages laboriously, then throws the book to   the ground. Stanley doesn't pick it up and just watches   the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch your bloody step!     Right? They return to their car and drive off. Stanley looks at them thoughtfully, then picks up his book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the students are in classes. Cloete walks        out classroom and sees Capt. Stolz walking towards       the ing. Cloete stops to wait for him. They shake         han walk to Cloete's office talking affably. They        ente office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Susan in bed, asleep. The PHONE RINGS... waking them both. Ben answers. There's no one there. He puts it down. The RINGING STARTS AGAIN. Ben puts the re- ceiver down. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Ben, please stop whilst there's time. Please, Ben. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (focusing on ceiling) It's impossible to stop now, Susan. I believe I'm right in what I'm doing. If I stop now I'll go mad. SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (despaired) Whatever the price you pay for it? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (painfully) I have got to. Susan shuts her eyes tight and turns her back on him to hide her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a functional office. Picture of the South African president (1976) John Vorster, on the wall. Various staff pictures... Ben, summoned by Cloete, sits. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of your heritage, man. My God -- think of your wife, your family, friends, neighbors. What's going to happened to them -- all of us -- if we can't depend on our own kind? We're educationalists -- teachers. We are building for the future. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without simple justice we don't deserve a future. CLOETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're Boers, man -- Afrikaners. We are your nation. What's justice for us is justice -- period! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traitors like you are threatening centuries of Afrikaner sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That last remark was slanderous -- I'm simply being faithful to the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slanderous? My God, man, you slander a whole people. He walks silently through the office then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have given me no alternative. I have to abide by the regulations of the Department of Education -- so I have made my report. And there will have to be a formal inquiry. But until such time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't be necessary, Mr. Cloete. I'll send you my resignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for making things much easier. Ben stares at him for a moment, then turns to leave.    A he reaches the door, Cloete says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it would be better if Johan left too. Ben turns to stare at him, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a Kaffir-lover too, isn't he? The color drains from Ben's face. Then he steps forward, slaps Cloete thunderously across the face, hurling him back into his chair, and strides out, leaving the door ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the school day. The yard is practically deserted. Only Viviers waiting for Ben under the veranda. Ben appears. VIVIERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oom Ben, I was waiting for you. I have something interesting to tell you. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (striding on towards his car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Viviers. VIVIERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping up) But, Oom Ben, it's about the S.B. they came to question me. Before they started questioning me I told them they were wasting their time. Ben doesn't react. VIVIERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They asked if I was cooperating with you. What I knew about the A.N.C. Can you imagine that! They then said: 'Mr. Viviers you come from a good Afrikaans family and it's important that you realize that communists are looking for people like you and before you know where you are they're using you! And, Oom Ben... BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching the car; interrupting him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Viviers. I never wanted you to get involved. (getting into his car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have just resigned. VIVIERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) What...? Ben drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas day lunch. Assembled around the table are Ben's Father-in-law, his wife Helen, Suzette and Chris, her husband, Johan, Ben and Susan. They're all wearing paper hats from Christmas crackers. On the table is a large piece of roast lamb, ox tongue, a large turkey and assorted vegetables. Ben is at the head of the table adjacent to the door lead ing to the kitchen, the Father-in-law is sitting by his side facing the door. Ben is in the middle of carving the turkey, plates are being passed to him. JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was last year's turkey as big as this, Papa? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the same size. SUZETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember the turkey I had for Easter? You said it was as big as a baby ostrich, Papa. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember that, Suzette. FATHER-IN-LAW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Johan, when I was a boy in the Karoo, we used to fry ostrich eggs. You know how big they are? JOHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) As big as this table. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Father-in-law) I think he deserves the parson's nose for that remark. They laugh. Susan laughs. She does her best to compose. Suddenly... a KNOCK at the outside kitchen door. As Ben turns towards the door it opens and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Stanley erupts into the kitchen like a great black bull in white suit and white shoes. A scarlet tie is matched by a huge handkerchief hanging from his pocket. He is a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obviously surprised by this family scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! (then grinning and laughing thunderously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, everyone! There's deadly quiet -- not even the clink of a spoon -- as the Du Toits look on aghast. Slowly, as if in a dream, Ben rises and goes to Stanley who spots him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Lanie'... compliments of the season, old mate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley.   What are you doing here? Before Stanley answers, the Father-in-law gets up from hi chair and goes to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this Kaffir, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell the Boer who this Kaffir is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Stanley. (to Father-in-law)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. I'll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quivering with rage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Kaffir calling me a Boer? Chris hurries into the kitchen ready for a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, did you hear that?   Call the police, Ben!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Father-in-law)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, go to the table. (to Stanley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley, wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fuming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these people, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley, this is still my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me throw him out. Ben steps between them and pushes Chris back into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him try, leave him, Lanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Father-in-law)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please leave me with him.   I'll explain everything later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing has changed in this house. Mother, let's go! He strides into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan sits   with her eyes tight shut -- trying to shut o the horror   of it all. As the Father-in-law goes into the living   room, he pulls back his wife's chair and hel her to her   feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's leave this house. I've been sworn at by a Kaffir and Ben protects him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris! Chris follows. Susan also. From the living room, she calls Johan who is left alone at the table, perplexed. Johan goes to his mother. There's a general rush for the door and, without warning, the room is empty. Only the TIN ANGELS TINKLE merrily around their candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with cascading laughter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lanie! Ever in your fucking life seen such a stampede, hah? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Maybe you think it's funny, Stanley, but I don't. Do you realize what you've done? (he sighs deeply) Come into the dining room. Stanley follows Ben slowly, swaying. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Jeez, who was that old cunt with the potbelly and black suit, looks like an undertaker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben sits on his chair. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father-in-law. (deliberately) M.P. STANLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting beside Ben) You joking! (he laughs) Shit! I fucked it all up for you. Sorry, man. He laughs again.   Ben cannot take it anymore. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now pull yourself together, Stanley. It's not funny at all! What's the matter with you today? You're drunk and making an idiot of yourself. Say what you've come to say. Otherwise, go to hell! Stanley's laughter changes into a broad grin. He sur- veys the table and takes a bit of turkey from a plate and starts to eat it quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Dead right. Put the Kaffir in his place. Ben grabs him by the shoulders and starts to shake him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody hell! Stanley, what's wrong with you? Stanley shoves Ben off, and glares at him, bloodshot eyes breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily is dead. Ben stares at him in stunned disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily dead?   How?   When? Stanley doesn't answer - he cries. Ben grabs him by the shoulders and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Stanley?      Oh, my God. Please tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (between two sobs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A broken heart. All they said. Ben's hand still on Stanley's shoulder, he sits slowly beside him, shaken, his face ravaged by the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. Through the window, he sees Suzette and Chris carrying suitcases, back down the path to his in-laws' car; Father-In-Law shepherding his wife and an ashen, dazed Susan, helping them into the car. As they leave see Johan leaning against the dining room door, watching his father and Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very tense Ben is sitting on Professor Bruwer's chair. Melanie is curled up on the old settee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know what you've got and you're a danger to them. I know there's a point of no return, but with our system, one has to plot the route with care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the main reason for coming here tonight. Melanie, I need your help. Without Emily, we can't pursue our civil suit. The only thing left open to us is to expose them through the press, and the media here and abroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your safety also, Ben, lies in the press. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way the world will know the brutality and power of our security services; here questions can be asked in Parliament. And the white public can appreciate the implications of the fascist laws of this country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Melanie, I'm discovering that the enemy is not in Soweto. The enemy is ourselves. Our bigotry, our laws, our system. We have our own fight and it's just beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better win before the blacks have won. Ben and Melanie laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, before going to the press, I have to have all the documents. I must have two vital affidavits; Dr. Hassiem's, he's detained and Jonathan's friend, Wellington has fled to Zambia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zambia? I'm going to Rhodesia... I can go to Zambia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I can use my British passport. I know my way around Lusaka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be very useful. Melanie jumps off the settee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This calls for a drink.    Gin and tonic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. As Melanie walks away, Ben looks at her with admiration and tenderness... her dress swinging around her legs... her bare feet soundless on the floor... the quiet grace of her movement. On the way to the kitchen to get the drinks, Melanie goes to the record player. There's a record already on the turntable. Suddenly as if rising from a dream, Ben murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie.   Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she plays the record and flippantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Ben. She goes into the kitchen. As Melanie hums to herself to     the BLUES MUSIC, in the kitchen, Ben walks over to the     window and furtively glances out, to assure himself     that nobody is watchin He takes then a book on a pile     next to the settee and pages slowly through it. Melanie returns with two glasses, still in her happy mood. She places Ben's glass on the side table next to the settee, takes the book from him and makes him sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers! Ben raises his glass and touches it with hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do be careful. I wouldn't want you hurt. She reaches for his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with gentleness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And hurry back. A new track starts on the RECORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my favorite, Ben. Jumping up and taking Ben's glass and placing it on the side table, she pulls him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rugger player? They laugh as they start to dance to the slow BLUES MUSIC. The laughing subsides as they hold each other closer. The dancing starts to lose the beat of the music. They look into each other's eyes and Ben envel- ops her tenderly in his arms hugging her as close as possible against him. They stop dancing.     Ben kisses her.   A long, warm and tender kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Melanie in bed. He is kissing her and fondling her passionately. During the love play, Ben reaches for the lightswitch of the bedside lamp, and knocks it over. They make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is shopping at the local supermarket. He    is pushin a trolley. As he places some groceries into    his trolle he notices a man standing near the check-out   counters. The man is similar built as Jamie and similar   hairstyle He's reading a newspaper, his face concealed. Ben drops the package he was inspecting, back on the shelf and pushes his trolley towards the man to try and see his face. The man moves away. Ben follows him and has decided to confront him. Man picks up a pack of ham. Ben is about to remonstrate with him. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you... Just then a LADY and her daughter hurry to the man, push- ing a trolley. Man turns to look at Ben. WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, put that down, it's not good for your cholesterol. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the man) I'm sorry, my mistake. He pushes his trolley away embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The immaculate blue of the pool. Johan hurls himself out of the water, flops down at the side. Suzette and Ben nearby, sitting in the sun. Pieter at the barbecue, sizzling thick steaks. A servant in white uniform soundlessly laying the table on the patio behind him. The nanny with the baby in the shade. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- How's she doing? SUZETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better... She's waiting for you to ask her to come home. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She turns to Ben, squinting in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, I don't want to interfere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this is going to sound strange coming from me... I mean I haven't exactly been supportive for the past months... I can't say I agree with what you've done but I respect you for what you are... ON Johan listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just... destroyed by what's happening to us as a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts, squeezing his arm.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Papa, for Mom's sake... For all of our sakes... Let's try and patch it up. Ben smiles sadly at her... Suzette understands.        Jo looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Johan in the car.        Suzette leans in through driver's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me know if there's anything I can do to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.   I'm glad you understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to worry about you. That search, this vandalism, those shots... they're really after the evidence you've been accumulating ... Can I look after them for you, Papa? Ben smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to worry.   They'll never find them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where on earth do you keep them? ON Johan looking at Suzette then at Ben with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben has parked his car in a street corner of the upmarket section of the Asian township. He peers around him, then walks away. Ben knocks at a door. The door is opened cautiously by DR. HASSIEM, a tall, handsome Indian, aged 35 years. His clothes are casual but expensive. His six-year-old daughter, large dark eyes, is clinging to his leg. We recognize the little girl of the photograph near the telephone, from earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Hassiem? I'm Ben Du Toit. I'm a friend of Gordon Ngubene's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inquest is over, Mr. Du Toit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me, Doctor. I've got to know what happened to Gordon. Dr. Hassiem looks shaky, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only came home yesterday. After three months in detention and now I'm banned and confined to the house. There's nothing I can do for you.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The little girl still clinging to his leg, watching Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it may be painful to you, Doctor, but I need to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I be sure you weren't actually sent by them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask Emily. Doctor, we are in the process of filing a civil claim. And your help is vital. Hassiem gives Ben a long look.    He picks up his daughte and opens the door fully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. Ben walks into the large living room, tastefully furnished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. Ben is still looking 'round at the opulence.       He sit a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for inviting me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the little girl on his knees)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one thing, Doctor. Why did you sign the State Pathologist's report on the autopsy if you drew up your own report as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disconcerted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think I signed Dr. Jansen's report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The report produced in court had both your signatures on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you write in your report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Jansen and I didn't disagree on the facts. After all we examined the same body in the same time. But just on the interpretation. For example, if Gordon, had really been hanged, the marks on his throat would have been concentrated on the front. (he touches his larynx)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in this case, the bruises were more obvious on the sides. Pause.   Ben nods, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something else really upset me, perhaps it isn't important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it? Dr. Hassiem puts down his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, through a misunderstanding I arrived at the morgue too early for the autopsy. There wasn't a soul around except a young African attendant. When I told him I'd come for the autopsy, he let me in. The body was on the table dressed. I noticed blood on the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I examined the clothes more closely, a police-officer came in and said I wasn't allowed in the morgue before Dr. Jansen arrived. When I returned with Dr. Jansen, half an hour later, the body was naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, we've already got the African attendant's affidavit. He testified that Capt. Stolz ordered him to burn the clothes. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you mention what you said in your report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.   I found it most odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Hassiem would you be prepared to put that in writing? Dr. Hassiem thinks it over for a while then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please excuse me for a minute. Ben watches him leave the room, the little girl following him. He gets up from the chair, walks to the window, glances through it, then steps to look at some family photographs on the mantlepiece. Amongst them a photograph of Dr. Hassiem before "Big Ben." Dr. Hassiem returns with a file, the daughter still following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening the file)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my report. I only have one copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astounded)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a copy of the report? Hassiem grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how to hide things from the S.B., Mr. Du Toit. Ben congratulates him by a deep laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Dr. Hassiem working as a team, tape the type- written sheets of the report among a Rand Daily Mail newspaper pages at the back.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On Dr. Hassiem's desk we recognize next to the phone, the little girl's photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you have as secure a place as I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an accomplice smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A multi-storied building half-built. Stanley standing on the fourth floor watching Ben's arrival. Ben searches for Stanley who draws Ben's attention; beckons him up. Ben indicates they meet halfway. He joins Stanley who's sitting on a pile of bricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with expansive gesture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a pew, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting and excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have it, Stanley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hassiem's report. You know what that means, Stanley? Melanie arrives in two days. We'll have all the evidence. Everything is in place. We'll get them yet, especially Stolz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fantastic, man. Stanley produces from his jacket pocket a newspaper -- Rand Daily Mail. He opens it on a certain page with the picture of an African in police uniform, and hands it to Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God!   It's Johnson Seroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late at night. A knock on the door. He opened and five shots, point-blank range. Face, chest, stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'A police spokesman when questioned said: "It's not the first time that a black member of the police has lost his life in the service of his country, fighting terrorism." (folding paper in disgust)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody bastards! They killed him. Stolz must have thought he knew too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the score? The nurse is detained; the mortuary attendant has disappeared; the police van driver who brought Jonathan to hospital is detained. Julius is in jail, and now Johnson dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's next on their secret list, I wonder? How much longer must the list grow of those who pay the price of our efforts to clear Gordon's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Are you going soft, Lanie? We must keep going even more so now. And for every bloke who's going to die of bloody natural causes in their hands. And for our children's future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. If I can no longer believe that right is on my side, if I can no longer believe in imperative to go on, what will become of me, Stanley? Ben looks at Johnson's picture again and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 8x10 black and white photograph on Ben's desk.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On the photograph a naked man and a girl on a bed and a bedside lamp on its side. The man is Ben and the girl is Melanie. Stolz in sports jacket, standing next to the desk is speaking... patronizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all made of flesh and blood, Mr. Du Toit -- we've all got our flaws. And if a man likes to sample the grass on the other side of the fence, well, that's his own business. But it would be unpleasant if people found out about it, especially if he's a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, if I cooperate, if I stop digging, embarrassing you, threatening you... these photographs will disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say I may be able to use my influence to make sure that a private indiscretion isn't used against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I refuse? Stolz looks past Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your son? Ben whirls around to see Johan at the door. He shoots, puts himself between the photograph and his son obviously surprised to find Capt. Stolz there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johan, leave us alone, please. Johan walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think this business has gone long enough? Ben, struggling to maintain his composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for you people to decide. Isn't it? I won't be blackmailed, Captain -- not even by you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I smoke? Ben answers by a gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after lighting his cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now be honest. Has all the evidence you've been collecting in connection with Gordon Ngubene brought you closer to the truth you are looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so and there's more to come. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really hoped we could talk man-to-man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not possible, Captain.    Not between you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's high time, Mr. Du Toit, we allowed the dead to rest in peace. I'm offering you a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean my very last chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One never knows. It may not be important to you, but we have to survive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can only survive through murder and torture, then we have forfeited our right to exist. Slowly and deliberately Stolz stubs out his cigarette in the ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your final answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you go. I'll tell this, Captain. I have a pretty good idea of what I will eventually uncover. I mean the truth. And I won't allow anyone or anything to come between me and that truth. Ben walks up to the door to see him out. There's no response from Stolz. He calmly takes a small card out of his pocket and rests it on Ben's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my card -- my private line. If you should change your mind... Let's say before the end of the week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Captain, and don't forgt the photograph. Stolz picks up the photograph and puts it into his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful, Mr. Du Toit. There are people who can make things very difficult for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are wasting their time. They just can't hurt me anymore. I trust you'll give them the message, Captain. He walks out. Ben follows him 'round the garage and watches him get into his car and drive away. Johan joins his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mischievous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brandy, Papa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling back, ruffling his hair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gin and tonic would be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Johan are standing in the public enclosure on the top floor of the airport building. Ben is unshaved, he looks tired, but happy. There is the usual bustle of airport staff for the steps and luggage, two-thirds of the staff being black. Passengers emerge from the plane Melanie amongst them. Some waving to friends and relatives on the public en- closure. Melanie stops momentarily and looks up at the enclosure. She sees Ben and Johan and waves at them. They wave back and Ben indicates they'll be waiting for her below. She walks off as they happily await her after the ususal formalities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Johan are waiting outside the arrivals exit. Several passengers stream out, some being met. Eventually there is a trickle of passengers. An INDIAN WOMAN is one of the last to come out. Ben approaches her. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
