dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm waiting for a lady with a red dress. Are there still, many people to come? INDIAN WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did see her. She was ahead of me. Maybe she's still in there. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Just then an OFFICIAL walks out of the door.   Ben hurrie to him. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for a passenger, Miss Bruwer. She's taking a rather long time to be cleared. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say her name was? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie Bruwer. OFFICIAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go and check.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Official hurries back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any other exit, Papa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They have to collect their luggage and pass through customs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she can't find her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smilng back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's possble. Just then Stolz appears through the door. He slowly walks up to Ben and Johan. Ben becomes apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Meneer Du Toit.   Johan, isn't it? Ruffling his hair; Johan pulling away and glaring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Word came to me that you were asking after your very good friend, Miss Bruwer. You know, subersives come in all guises and can be very resourceful. Now let's take your friend, she has been using her privilege as a journalist to endanger the security of this country. But you know something else? She has been secretly holding a British passport. A South African passport and a British pasport. Now you tell me, where is her patriotism? Her allegiance? The minister telexed to the immigration officers here declaring her an undesirable immigrant. So she is being put on the first available plane to London. This must be heart- breaking for you. Good afternoon, Meneer Du Toit, Johan. Stolz walks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go home, Johan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, Papa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (striding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll explain later. They hurry out of the building in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Johan arriving at the house. An unsympathetic small crowd is there waiting... They react, murmuring in Afrikaans, watching them with hostility as Ben and Johan get out of the car and discover the chaos. The wreckage. The garage and Ben's study have been bombed. Johan leaves Ben and rushes to the house. The crowd starts to disperse. The entire    tools cupboard has been methodically ripped apart and    the contents strewn on the garage floor. Everything    is half-burnt... charred... Ben has sunk on the stool    in total defeat. There's silence. Then Johan appears at the door. He hands Ben a large envelope -- in it, the file with all the papers. Ben look up at Johan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very proud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took it out. Hide it in my secret place. Ben grabs his son, hugs him and holds on for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, son. You did a man's job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is sitting at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Before him, scattered on the table: the affidavits he collected, the Hassiem report, cuttings of articles by Melanie in the Rand Daily Mail about Jonathan, newspaper pictures of Gordon, of Seroke, of himself with Emily, the half-burnt "peace painting" of Picasso, half-burnt photo of Ben with Suzette, a staff photograph, Ben amongst it, and a charred trophy. Ben starts putting material relevent to his inquiries into a large brown envelope. Johan enters kitchen with a large envelope and hands it to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody has dropped it through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm nearly ready, Papa. Ben examines the unstamped envelope with his address, with curiosity then opens it. The contents is Wellington's affidavit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wellington's affidavit! He looks inside the envelope, expecting a personal note. There's none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old Melanie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johan is packing his sport kit and few clothes into a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Johan are walking towards the entrance, Johan wheeling his bike. Ben hugs his son.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Johan gets on the bike and rides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is pouring coffee. He looks tired and tensed. The PHONE RINGS in the living room. He hurries to answer it. Who knows, could be Melanie from the airport!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben picks up the phone.    A menacing male voice says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meneer du Toit, tonight we're coming to kill you. Ben replaces the receiver obviously shaken.     He become aware of FOOTSTEPS approaching the kitchen.     Ben is terrified. A KNOCK at the door and the door swings open:     it's Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happened, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obviously still scared)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's you. It was a bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Safe. Thanks to Johan. Incidentally, I have Wellington's affidavit. Melanie found him. She's being deported. The official reason is that she possessed a British passport. I don't know how she managed to smuggle the envelope to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, it's all happening! Stanley walks out, glances at the devastated study. He reenters the kitchen and slams on a chair. He takes a packet of "Lucky Strike" from his pocket and offers it to Ben

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a joint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. Stanley lights a cigarette and surveys the table. He picks up the half-burnt Picasso book, gives it a brief glance, and tosses it back on the table and starts to chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drop the bomb on you! Ben walks up to him puts his hand on his shoulder. There's an understanding trace of a smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben sitting in a cafe smoking his pipe.   A waiter serves him a glass of beer, for which he pays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining. Stanley driving in the rain on the same road as Johan.

dialogues.speaker: PARKED CAR
dialogues.text: Suzette's sports car pulls up outside the cafe where Ben is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben rises as Suzette joins him at his table.   They kiss and she sits opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at her straight in the eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Suzette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a soft voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. Without taking his eyes off her, he takes a brown envelop from a chair and pushes it slowly towards the uncomfor- table Suzette. She picks up the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Suzette awkwardly kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look after them. Suzette looks at him for a moment and hurries to her car. As Suzette leaves, Ben turns back into the room, his eyes glassy with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette gets into her car and drives off. The parked car follows. The two cars turn at the next corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two cars approach following each other. As the second car overtakes, he draws Suzette's attention with his HORN and signals her to pull up. As she gets out of her car holding the brown envelope, Capt. Stolz gets out of the other side. Suzette walks over to the passenger:      Colonel Viljoen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you got the goodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on my way to your office, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought we'd save you the trouble, Mrs. Klopper. She hands Viljoen the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. This country needs more people like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must hurry, Colonel.   Goodbye. She drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stolz gets into the car as Colonel Viljoen starts open- ing the brown envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's see what we've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley is parked near the building. He's drumming on the steering wheel to the rhythm of AFRICAN MUSIC from his car RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viljoen has just finished opening the brown envelope. He pulls out the half-burnt Picasso book and Captain Stolz's card which he gave to Ben. On the card is written: "APARTHEID MUST GO" TOT SIENS (goodbye)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ben Du Toit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johan hurries out of the building and is about to get on his bike. His attention is drawn by Stanley's familiar HOOTER. Johan turns, sees Stanley, and with a grin makes thumbs- up sign which happy Stanley returns with his large thumb. Johan cycles away followed by Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben looks at his watch. He goes to the cash desk and pays. He walks slowly out of the cafe. Stands at the door to find his car keys; the rain has emptied the street. Ben turns up his collar and waits for a break in the traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Stolz alone in the car.        He drives around t corner into the cafe street. Just then, Ben is hurrying across the road to his car. Captain Stolz sees him, accelerates and hits Ben, hurling him high into the air. And speeds away. People rush to Ben's side... crowd quietly gathers. FREEZE FRAME and...
